RfqauZ1r3btCbfsrhigldw.review_text: I ate here a few months ago with my boyfriend. He asked me last night when we were coming back. I realized that I had wanted to post a review but life got in the way. We made a reservation on a Tuesday evening. The place was packed. We were promptly greeted and sat. Our server, Aldo was amazing and on point. He was knowledgeable about the food and made great recommendations.The support staff were also on point. The food runner dropped each dish with an description of the food. The bussers cleared with efficiency. Another server filled our empty wine glasses before we got a chance to realize we even needed a refill. I work in the industry and appreciate team work when I see it.  We ordered the blistered peppers, deviled eggs, crudo, lamb skewers and the duck. Every dish was presented well and yummy. We ordered a second deviled eggs before dessert because they were that good. The lamb skewers and crudo were my favorite. The eggs and duck were my boyfriend's favorite.   Yes the prices were a bit high but the quality of food, service, atmosphere and experience was worth it. I never ate at the old Fog City so I can't compare the two but I do recommend it to friends and customers that ask me of a great place to eat in the city. I will be back soon and can't wait to have those lamb skewers again. FYI: the blistered peppers added to the lamb skewers is delish!

oLkCENbfUHq5Y3_fCr5rrA.review_text: Wonderful service, food, drinks, dessert, and atmosphere!   Our waiter knew the menu like the back of his hand. He offered suggestions and was precise. He was patient with our group and didn't make us feel rushed while still maintaining a steady service pace.   The food. The food. I will definitely be returning and spending my hard earned money here. I mean they can just take it by the barrels. P.S. I really want to try the drink they have aging in that barrel in the bar area. Cheeseburger was delicious. I had a bite of the salmon dish also great. I might have that next time.   My drink had milk in it. It was citrusy and sweet and delicious. Waiter knew what he was talking about. I really wish I remembered his name. If you're reading this, thank you, thank you, thank you. I had a wonderful dining experience because of you.  The dessert. The pumpkin bread pudding with pumpkin spice ice cream and caramel bourbon sauce was orgasmic. It could have it's own review.   That night I slept well. Food coma survivor extraordinaire here.

gOBFkLsR6gfpJ378ND4ykA.review_text: The food is just okay. In fact they brought me the wrong hamburger. Instead of offering to make another burger the server said they were still ironing out the kinks since the place reopened several weeks ago. I paid $14.00 for the hamburger and $6 for cold fries. Never again at Fog City.

56Y__3lMsc_i1bwc9ML92A.review_text: Multiple special occasion had been spent here in past. College graduation, engagement, romantic dinners. This past Saturday has changed my view and loyalty. The remodel was nice by opening up the floor. We had a drink at the bar while we waited for our table. Once seated we asked for bread three times, ordered our appetizers and entrees. Bread came after a long wait. Water was poured for some and the pitcher was left empty. Food quality was over all good. In a city of vegans and vegetarians not one item off and on the menu existed. It was looked down upon when we asked for lemon to flavor the blan cauliflower. Food came to the table we did not order and billed us for. Vegetable sides came after entrées.  The menu should be labelled with small plates and big plates because the portions of some items are on the small side.

12q5Bup5oxkhZqAXPHkNJw.review_text: Enjoyed dinner here in a busy Sunday evening. Great service. Minimalist decor, dim lighting. Nice, yet casual, environment. Good sized bar and drinks. Dinner for two ran about $110-ordered 1 beer, 2 cocktails, a fig salad, hamachi crudo, deviled eggs & lamb skewers. All were good-would definitely return!

8PB0zJe6oPmiIK1eOmk38A.review_text: It was really loud.  The food was not as good as it used to be.  The ambiance was like a bar more than a restaurant.  Did I say it was loud?  I guess it was wishful thinking that the old Fog City Diner would remain unchanged, sad.  The food was $$$.  Nothing sticks in my head as particularly good for that price range, 2 out of 5 I would say.  The service was 3 out of 5.  I'm not going back.  The one thing I liked was the communal seating.  Had a good conversation with a stranger.  That was fun.

7gNtYzygF7dB8e7k1mWdjA.review_text: I first dined at Fog City through a YEE held here last month. (yelp.com/biz/elite-event…) As I showed the No1DP the pictures and explained what I had that night, he saw how much fun I had at the event and wanted to experience the restaurant himself the next time he saw me. I came back here one month later with the No1DP and friend/fellow Yelper Aren A., who initially took me to the YEE here as his +1. CONCEPT: Originally known as the Fog City Diner before dropping the "diner" label. Looking from previous pictures no decor from the original restaurant remain, save the views of the Embarcadero. What did remain were the core elements of what made this restaurant famous - small plates. VENUE: Looks to be an upscale "diner" with the more overt diner decorations removed - hues of brown enumerate the area. There's a big central bar area with the booths circling the bar. SERVICE: Excellent service. She warned us about the long prep time for the chicken and offered to replace my drink when the No1DP accidentally toppled over my Milk Punch. COCKTAILS - Milk Punch, $11 (Bourbon, Brandy, Rum, Citrus & Spices, Sugar, Clarified Milk). This was my cocktail throughout the night as I fell in love with it back at the YEE. I could not taste any hint of the alcohol as everything in this drink was mixed well. - Grandpa's Breakfast, $12 (Famous Grouse Scotch, Allspice Dram, Combier Kummel, Lemon, Honey, Whiskey Barrel Bitters). One of No1DP's drinks. He enjoyed his drink as the whiskey and ingredients went smoothly. I liked it because of the cup it was served in, which is more appropriate for coffee. - Paper Chase, $11 (Junipero Gin, Cappelletti Apertivo, Dolin Dry, Raspberry). One of Aren's drinks, tasted "too much like Robitussin". We eventually told our waitress, who took it off the final bill. PLATES - Local Oysters on the Half Shell, $3.50/oyster (Oak Barrel Aged Hot Sauce, Shallot Mignonette). Oysters were a bit on the small side. The hot sauce and mignonette went well with the brine. - Deviled Eggs, $8 (Grain Mustard, Crispy Quinoa, Bacon). Fell in love with this at first bite at the YEE. The creamy egg serve as base for the crispy quinoa and bacon. - Iacopi Farms Brussels Sprouts, $10 (Asian Pear, Ponzu, Togarashi). Didn't like the pears but the togarashi spices gave the sprouts a slight spicy kick. - Crab Cakes, $11 (Basil Aioli, Oven Charred Cherry). The actual crab cake was decent but the taste improved with the aioli, which didn't have too much basil. - Broccoli Di Cicco, $11 (Flame Grilled with Lemon, Garum, Fiordolio Olive Oil, Garlic Chips). Tasted a lot like broccoli but there was so much flavor into the garlic chips. - Wood Oven Whole Chicken, $38 (Brentwood Corn, Bacon, Fingerling Potatoes, Kimchi Butter, Spiced Salt). This is actually a larger plate but we treated it as a small plate and final dish. You have to order this in advance as it takes at least 30 minutes cook time. The meat was tender and juicy all through the chicken - no dry spots on the breast. Rub was simple yet delicious. The corn and potatoes took some of the chicken juice and as a result went well with the chicken. SWEETS - The "B" Bomb, $7 (Glazed French Cruller, Vanilla Frozen Custard, Egg Yolk Caramel). My dessert, as I still wanted some of the frozen custard. I realized it looked and tasted like a fancy donut with fancy ice cream. Though I liked my dessert it was a bit on the plain side. - Pumpkin Brioshe (sic) Bread Pudding, $8 (Bourbon Caramel Sauce, Pumpkin Spiced Ice Cream). Aren's dessert. A solid piece of bread pudding, though I didn't taste much pumpkin. - Panna Cotta Pudding Cake, $8 (Dark Chocolate, Milk Chocolate, Caramel, Candied Peanuts). No1DP's dessert, the chocolate smooth yet not too rich. Candied peanuts are made to be eaten with the dessert. I should've ordered this dessert instead. FINAL BILL: ~$245. I look forward to trying more small plates here. Note that the Milk Punch and the Frozen Custard are on the 7x7 Big Drink and Big Eat, respectively.

jC-LuL1IEU8TJp342DmWKw.review_text: It's rare when every dish you get at a restaurant is perfect. It happened here. From the rustic sourdough bread (oh my god) to the Brussels Sprouts to the amazing whole chicken.... everything perfect. The chicken is really a complete meal. It has these amazing vegetables that cook in the chicken's juices and really, this dish is a religious experience. The beer was cold, the crowd was cool and the host and waiter were so nice. I cannot wait to return!

Snio_QiJPDPrtrL6GXkb9Q.review_text: Good location. Food is tasty. A little pricey but I would come back.

sRkBYod0y2OjIHtpw4gSWA.review_text: Best place in town. We were going to see Avett Brothers in concert at America's Cup Pavilion and picked the closest place for a lite bite, we actually went in 3 times. Once to get directions to another restaurant, luckily for us it wasn't open. The second time to check out the place and went to look for other options, the 3rd time was to eat. We were starving! We were SO glad we came back to this place. We sat at the bar, talked with the bartender the whole time, he was so great, watching him work was so much fun and entertaining, learning all about mixing cocktails, chatting with us the whole time but working extremely hard and efficiently for the waiter staff. We had amazing fries and a fabulous classic burger. Had the opportunity to speak with Bruce, the chef/owner who is a down to earth, friendly guy who clearly takes pride in his restaurant and rightly so. We had a great time, learned about different types of food and drink, it was a great atmosphere, we'd definitely go back and sit at the bar. They have a community table that is on a first come basis along with the bar, reservations are definitely required for tables. Food was superb, thanks Bruce, see you again soon!!! G&G

lMLPQoeBq77bYxFvvcgvZA.review_text: I've wanted to try this place for some time and had the perfect opportunity after a Yelp party on the Hornblower. When we arrived it was probably closer to 10 pm on a Saturday night, the place was semi full, we asked for a booth and the polite hostess seated us at the bar while we waited for a booth. We've always come across this place when there have been a long wait. Not this time!   We waited maybe ten minutes, I had enough time to order a drink before we were seated at a comfy booth looking out onto the street. I already had my drink in hand and our server took hubby's order of coffee when we seated. Coffee was good, I point this out, because, we've ordered coffee at other places and we can't keep track of the number of places who serve crappy coffee on the off hours! Fog City is everything I imagined, cool, vibrant, superb service! Great ambiance, great lighting,great people watching and great atmosphere! We probably should've felt under dressed, we were dressed in our SF attire, looking like total tourists(dressed to look the part for our Yelp party). We were dressed in SF hoodies, and sneakers, lol! Never felt out of place. Noticed that there were others who were dressed to the "Nines" but couldn't pay for their bills, lol! How many times does the place have to decline your credit card, people!! Yup, saw that you paid in cash after so many rejections.   We quickly glanced over the menu, ordered the cheeseburger and the Chinese chicken salad, we mentioned to our server that we will be sharing both and when our food came out, the cheeseburger was cut in half and cooked EXACTLY the way we specified! Cool! The cheeseburger was similar to an In n Out burger with a better quality of meat. Cut symmetrically, with everything intact with every delicious bite! I also ordered a Miyagi oyster shooter, for the helluvit! I was in San Diego the week before and had the same oyster and it solidifies my judgement that the oyster in SD was not what I expected! The Chinese chicken salad satisfied all your senses with different textures and tastebuds were on overload with so many different tastes!   I'm not sure, there was a need for a server here, they provide you with a carafe of water, the food had absolutely no complaints, it was everything I had imagined! I will definitely come back if the place wasn't so damn busy. That's a good thing! It's pricey, but damn good!

ydeU5IZFEvvu_1JHKbWo9w.review_text: Came here twice, and ate;  Smoked salmon Brussel sprouts Clams Burger  Trout Plain French fries French fries with furikake  The only good thing was plain French fries...  The rest sucked and sat in my stomach for hours it made me sick.  Definitely overpriced.  Terrible quality food for what they charge it's insulting.

34CVzDSZcln9rlOjY15ZdQ.review_text: I came here for dinner and really wasn't expecting much from this place after reading previous Yelp reviews. It by far exceeded my expectations! We had great cocktails, and reasonably-priced good wine. While all the food was good, the deviled eggs, brussels sprouts and whole roasted chicken were particularly awesome!!

i8H141eI886jh4kuiE6i1g.review_text: Great menu. I went there for lunch so that's all I can speak to. Falafel sand which was good but the fries and the Brussel sprouts were worth coming here alone. Great location and record. I would certainly return, especially with out of towers. Only con is the expense, but that really isn't a con as its not exactly a secret.

y_jl-bErj1mnb4KF04F74Q.review_text: Great food options and drinks - but very loud - you need to shout at people across the table if you go when it is busy.

lxOcZ1VZ58nSCFgcunecjw.review_text: We had a great time out at Fog City this past weekend with a group of friends who also really enjoyed their experience.  Reservations were tough to come by and the six of us were sat in a booth but it all worked out.  Our waitress was a little interesting but the food made up for everything.  We started with the deviled eggs (awesome taste and loved the little bacon on there), brussel sprouts (so money), fries ( so good as well) and kale and farro salad.  We shared a bunch of entrees among them was the swordfish, pork chop and ribs.  Each were really good and prepared perfectly,  For dessert we got the strawberry shortcake, french cruellers and custard and all were a perfect way to finish the meal.  This is a new Fog City but in a good way.  The food will impress.

QI-oVGhqLNp5yO3fyGC8hg.review_text: I eat out often in San Francisco and was anxious to try the new Fog City.  The new decor is gorgeous but the food was, well, pretty bad.  I had the chicken sandwich and my husband had the sesame chicken salad but we shared the two dishes.  Both were only OK.  The chicken in the salad was gristly and there were strips of plain skin in the salad.  The salad was over-dressed and was one of the worst chicken salads I've had.  The sandwich came with coleslaw so we asked if we could substitute fries.  Our waitress said yes but later charged us $3 for the fries which she didn't mention up front.  We had strawberry shortcake for dessert, thinking maybe that would redeem the meal, but the berries didn't taste fresh and the biscuits had a weird flavor.  So overall, a big disappointment.  We won't be back.

ZvEOY2p6v0ORu3z3h-6VlA.review_text: Very good food. The lady at the entrance was rude. She asked us if we want to look at the menu before sitting down. Felt like she thought we couldn't afford the place :)

JIaACWmW5r2_1LULLjeP5Q.review_text: What you would think might be a tourist trap is actually a really decent restaurant for lunch or dinner.   Located close to the tourist area of Embarcadero (near pier 39), the Fog City Diner has some really good food specialties (clam chowder) and classic cocktails.  While not "on the water", it's close by and makes walks along the waterfront very special.

KUXfzl-Sc1wn2nkX-Slyww.review_text: Came here for dinner and was pretty pleased with the whole experience.   For apps, the cauliflower, fries, and deviled eggs are excellent.  For main course, the wood oven clams and swordfish are great as well.  I had never tried swordfish before, so I thought I would give it a shot here.  I was a bit surprised at how the swordfish came out (on the meaty side), though I hear that is simply how the fish tastes - and overall the dish was otherwise excellent as well.  For dessert, I had the frozen custard + egg yolk caramel and a French culler.  The caramel is definitely worth a try.

kOn2L4zlv9KqxLUxtPBveQ.review_text: I've eaten here at least six times in its new incarnation and could not be happier.  The food is simply outstanding, with impeccable, fresh-from-the-market ingredients and phenomenal flavors that explode on the palate.  The wood-fired broccoli is one of the best veg dishes I've ever eaten; I get it almost every time. But the artichokes, now in season, give it a run for the money. And the deviled eggs with crispy quinoa and bacon are divine, but I was also impressed with the dollops of ahi tuna tartare on bite-sized rice cakes.  All of the entrees have been delectable, from the savory whole deboned chicken to the delightful wild boar ribs to to spicy lamb skewers to just-caught fish specials.   I'm normally not a dessert person (I prefer a sweet cocktail such as the Fog City Milk Punch or the Wisconsin Fix, both remarkable) but the house-made custard with caramel sauce is out of this world.   Service is always excellent, but last night, Tobias took it to a new level. I felt like I was dining at a very attentive friend's house rather than a restaurant. Unparalleled service like that cannot be taught; it's innate in a person's heart.   Have I had a couple dishes I wasn't keen on? Sure, but other Yelpers have adored them. And nothing has sullied any visit enough to make me love this place less.  The incredible food, and the cocktails that are among the best in town, and the lovely service, and the fact that a manager always stops by, and the ambiance that's now chic and modern and fun, all add up to a winning experience for me every time.

hergQXcUDbw0LH2V5imeJQ.review_text: Delicious food, excellent service.  It's just way overpriced.  The prices indicate to me that they are a little full of themselves.   While we could have left when we looked at the menu, we were too tired to get up and leave, and my husband would have been embarrassed (not me!) so we stayed.   The pork french dip was delicious, my summer tomato salad was delicious, my husband's chicken sandwich was delicious, my mom's soup was delicious, the price for lunch for five (no alcohol) was $145.   That is just crazy.   But, it was really good.  So, you have been warned!!!!

KT0MJsONmQbNYqXfYF2QKQ.review_text: Way overpriced for the Quality of food.  Nice location.  service was ok... I will try somewhere different next time I am in that area of SF.

WSwA7mhnb8XmUC1_UpMQNQ.review_text: Good but not outstanding food and service at an outrageous price. Definitely a tourist trap for the Fisherman's Wharf crowd.

obC5UOkcegvjASnr4RKoxw.review_text: I gave this another try on a Friday night, and had arguably the best service I've ever had.  Wonderful guy, can't remember his name but he did say he was half-Mexican, half-Persian.  I think the first time I visited we got a trainee or something.  Will be back!

4zam0N_2wsqVaUAEXF8rXQ.review_text: Had a late lunch here yesterday with a group of four and we thought the whole experience, including the food was pretty uninspired and basic.

ia9WOAZ6eXMbNgr4wvmJ1g.review_text: Decent to good food but not kid friendly. No kids menu. My brother asked for chicken to be added to his salad and they refused. Minus one star for that. Hostess argued about putting a high chair at our table too but the waitress ignored it.

noMq6mZGhbI3krwL8qz1PA.review_text: excellent service and very solid food

DI7mg1oQHeUApMm-9Y-BGw.review_text: Fog City diner is not a diner so if you want Mels, go somewhere else. We attempted it on a whim one night last week because it was late, i wanted fish, and it was close. I had been to the old one a few times and was just put off by something ...not sure what it was but hadn't been back in years.   First off, the space is lovely. It's open with a v shaped bar and a woodfire kitchen- GREAT for a foggy SF night. Our waiter was hilarious and took great care of us. He approached us and simply said 'hi. want to split a bottle of wine?" clearly seeing what kind of gal I was. However, this night I order a drink instead.   And what a drink! 5 stars just for it. The kind of drink that you would finish in 30 seconds because it was so amazing. Make sure you order it- Fog City Milk Punch. Sounds totally gross, goes down so incredibly easy.   From there we got appetizers of oysters, fries, and broccoli, mains AND desserts. Everything was yummy- my partner loved the fries more than I did but i'm a steak fry kind of chick.  He got short ribs and I got the special of the day- wood-fired tuna. It sounded like it was going to be a mess but the olives, fish stock, beans....all came together with the fish.   I'm happy this place is by my house but my wallet is sad. It was a bit spendy for a "quick bite" after the gym but we did stay and eat our fill for two hours. I'll be back- next time for brunch.   A couple of notes- the table next to us ordered all veggie plates and they must have had 7 different types of non meat based dishes. A good bet for you cow savers. Our broccoli side dish was MASSIVE and I ate it warmed up in the oven for the next two meals.   Lastly, rumor has it they serve box lunch for noontimes. If you work around there, I would totally 100% check it out.

XtTe0SLLEXjonEsrLYr6OA.review_text: Let's talk about chicken. If you're like me, you usually avoid ordering chicken at restaurants b/c there's nothing worse than dry chicken. Well, I don't know how Fog City does it, but they're chicken is mouth watering moist. On the reals, I was saying "WOW" during every bite, and the chicken even stayed moist during our last few bites.  So if you want to experience an amazing whole chicken that'll serve two, swing by Fog City. Additional details of my visit are below:  My GF and I sat at the bar where we were served by Matt, the bartender. Awesome dude who is very friendly and attentive. Here's what we ordered:  Deviled Eggs: They add a piece of bacon to the top and sprinkle the egg with toasted quinoa...MIND BLOWN  Halibut Crudo Appetizer: The watermelon is a nice touch and it's good, but I wouldn't say it's the best I've had.  Wood Oven Chicken: DAMN GOOD  Apple Pie Dessert: Delicious

XmEywucVDyUP9VJ4SXGjzw.review_text: Fog City is new and with a team of heavy hitters behind it.  It shows in the food, the service, and in how such a newly reopened place can function so smoothly.  First off, tables are pretty well spaced. However, the room gets quite loud as it fills as the ceiling is quite low.  But I tend to like a venue with energy and Fog City has that.  I also like a place where the waitstaff knows the menu.  Fog City has that as well.  My lovely young server was able to describe and discuss the menu in detail and to make suggestions.    I started with wood grilled tomato soup that was topped with basil and stracciatella. The cheese made all the difference and elevated a nice bowl of soup to something considerably better.    Roasted baby carrots came with a mole sauce and slivered almonds.  The mole sauce and almonds were wonderful.  The carrots were somewhat pallid.  I had thought that the roasting would concentrate the sweetness of the vegetable but these remained bland.  Nevertheless, this was a nice appetizer.  Half a planked trout came with fingerling potatoes, olives, and a grilled lemon.  This was the highlight of my meal.  The trout was perfectly prepared.  Not overcooked and not messed with.  Just fresh, lovely fish to sate my appetite. The only way this plate could have been improved would have been to provide a small bowl of the mole sauce from my carrots for me to dip the potatoes into.    Fog City is on track to become a new, landmark restaurant in San Francisco.

a3EtM6osbyISrZyNuo7JKQ.review_text: Mediocre experience.  I was looking forward to the new Fog City, but cannot recommend it to friends.  Must agree with other reviewers, food was good, but service needed a lot of help.  Condescending and not much of a welcome at the door.  Sort of like a getting a tire change. The waiter  really had no time to come and check on us (and it was early in the eve), she was pretty busy chatting up this guy at the counter.  Overall disappointment, but will try again as brussel sprouts were the best.

uVzxkswQxGHrr7ZrX_ZMnA.review_text: On a night out with a girlfriend, we were trying to find a place next to FiDi during Rush Hour. "How about Fog City Diner?" "Ugh, seriously? Remember how bad the service was?" "Yea, but it got renovated remember?" "Uhhh? Did they renovate the staff?" So then became our first time after the renovation of Fog City Diner.  I had made an appointment on Open Table and then had called them ahead of time to say we were early. They were able to seat us. Wow! This is a remarkably different place. Hustling for a Friday night, beautiful new interior design. I spotted dish ware from Haven, Always beautiful pieces of high quality and locally made.  The bar is open, The kitchen is an open concept. The management serves as well as the staff.  We started with the hand cut furikake fries with garlic aioli. Amazing, filling, addicting. The pickled gold shrimp with fennel, sweet onion, celery, cilantro avocado, and serrano chiles had you tasting all the flavors. Wonderfuly prepared. The roasted duck leg with roasted raddichio, delicate  squash, asian pear, and Manadori Balsamic over the side salad was delicious. I even had to stop the waitress and ask where the Balsamic was from. It's an aged Balsamic from Italy.  Service was continuous. They were great with service, after every entree to stay in touch with each customer.Communal tables. Bar. Then table tops.  The only place I found disappointing were the French Cruellers. I love French Food, but this one had no taste.  WIll be back again. Everything great, and I love the new Fog City. Just don't get the French Cruellers.

vn14QI6xmHWAbCSRmp5_3Q.review_text: This place is not like it used to be. The service is bad and the food is not any better.  Over priced and not very good. Not much more can be said.

Equi11nuKInRA0fem4DN4g.review_text: First time that the new fog city! Everything was absolutely exquisite with the exception of the rock music where dinner music (jazz) would've been appreciated! Will return again and again.

qJDHXse4y0rJOiV7rO8KOA.review_text: Fog City...Oh Fog City.   I actually really used to like Fog City before the renovation. You know, when it was still a legitimate diner and serving up delicious truffle fries without adding on shit tons of Furikake seasoning. But then they went and renovated it and alright, alright it really is beautiful! It is a complete transformation and worthy of applause. The wood fire kitchen is my favorite part- it really sets the tone.   But here's what I didn't love- I had a reservation for two but was not seated until 15 minutes after the reservation in spite of there being MANY open tables. I ordered the burger and while I love a delicious bougie SF burger, I can still get down with regular burgers to the liking of In-N-Out, Roam, etc. NEVER AGAIN. This was the worst burger I've ever had and I am shocked that anyone who has had the burger liked it enough to give it a good review.  The bun was soggy. The lettuce was sparse. The meat didn't really taste like anything and was a thin patty. You pay $15 for a shitty burger that doesn't even come with fries. Man. I got through about 2 bites and called it quits.  The service was shotty. They didn't even come around enough for me to tell them the burger was unpleasant. When our server did come around, she looked already irritated. Also, it took 45 minutes for us to get our two orders of fries, a burger, and soup. It was a situation where every table around us seemed to be getting their food before us which I might be more understanding of if our food was outstanding but it just wasn't.   In the restaurant's defense (and the reason for the extra star or else it really would be a one star), they comped the burger off the bill and was apologetic about it. But I will not be back at Fog City.

keyjMjGU6p46Pu45YFKaxg.review_text: Dinner started out great with amazing apps!  Brussel sprouts and Deviled eggs... Got roasted Chicken was ok however prob could have cooked something better at home.  The part that pissed everyone off at the dinner table was the fact that the french fries were covered in Nori and fish food flakes... literally the stuff you used to feed to your pet goldfish... You decide for yourself...

JeS7ciQNAY6seqFVrhsIuw.review_text: We had a really fun evening here -- it's loud & boisterous, but you're actually better off that way because of the acoustics of the main dining room.   Cocktails are very well made.  The dishes we tried trended towards spicy and a little salty, and I wonder how consistent the seasoning will be, since one thing really needed salt and I don't remember any being on the table.    I notice a few Yelpers experience sub-par service -- i thought the service we got was very good though.     It's such a great location along the water; and I'm really glad they seem to have gotten the old Fog City groove back (before the re-launch, it had gotten really kind of sad.)   We'll definitely be back.

5MusOgK528q7uyGw0H9MVQ.review_text: Beautiful remodel! Huge bar that wraps around the restaurant. Great food with a varied menu. Kale salad ** brussel sprouts** burger** winners!!

SqSMWBHD2Lklf_8W5MftPA.review_text: Had a great dinner at Fog City last week with guests in town. We picked it because of the location, but the food was pretty great. The roast chicken was delicious (not quite Zuni Cafe-delicious, but really good), and even the cabbage in the skillet was good. The star of the night, however, was the roasted carrots with mole, which was unlike anything I've had before. It was so good we ordered a second plate of carrots. We also enjoyed the asparagus, deviled eggs, and brussels sprouts (which were some of the best ones I've had that didn't include bacon or pancetta). The cocktails were also pretty good, especially the barrel-aged Saboteur. Unfortunately, they lose a star because the service didn't quite live up to the food. Our waiter would disappear for long periods of time, and it took us an abnormally long time to get and pay our check. The food was a little bit on the pricey side too, but nothing too surprising considering we're in SF. It's a cool space with a good location, so I'm pretty sure I'll be back in the future, probably when I have more guests in town.

vCpqH5qbs36s7AQBu64yOw.review_text: I don't like change, but I'm reconsidering my position based on my experience at Fog City.   This is brilliant reinvention. The space still feels special (in the way that the diner felt special in the 80s), but now it's polished, open, and sophisticated. It feels current without being precious. The staff are warm and welcoming in an authentic way. And the food is beyond delicious.   Those fries with the nori on top? Seriously? We loved them. (As did everyone else; we saw them on every table and at the bar.) I'd go back for the spicy pole beans any day of the week - amazing. A lady even grabbed my arm as I walked in and she walked out, and she whispered, "lamb skewers" in my ear. Didn't know her, but she was looking out for me. (That really happened.) And the plum sauce over the frozen custard was the perfect ending.   It's rare for a dining space of this size to exude a certain happiness from staff and patrons alike, but Fog City does. I'm happy it's happy.

KZazCSfV4oyRWcCukVBMPA.review_text: As a long time Fog City Diner patron I was excited to experience their new venture, I was both open minded but also aware of its past.  As we arrived the restaurant we were impressed by the new design and overall attention to detail. Much of the old experience is gone (minus a similar booth setup), but the new design is both crisp and tasteful.  Unfortunately however, anything good about the new concept stops at good design.  The Menu:  The menu is not at all reminiscent of the old class Fog City Diner. I get it, they wanted to drop the diner concept and move into something more upscale and sophisticated.  The new approach is "small plates" something that has gained popularity among restaurants over the past few years.  Personally, I'm not a fan of tapas style with this type of cuisine, but I understand it.   There are a few nice dishes on the menu ranging from a more simple butter lettuce salad to a more robust/hearty dish-- the chicken.  There's probably something for everyone on the menu, but I would have loved to see them keep a few or the original Fog City Diner dishes like their famous chicken paillard or their classic sourdough leek loaf. I think they could have pulled this off while still offering a fresh new innovative menu. It would have certainly kept all of its longtime patrons happy.   Our dishes all came out at the wrong time.  For example a cheesburger came out for one person (yes, I know it's intended to share, but not really practical to do so), but our chicken dish didn't come out for another 30 minutes.   All in all, the food was average but not up to Fog City Diner standards.  The Service:  To put it lightly, the service stunk. Our waiter was careless and often combative. We asked the status of our chicken dish that was over 30 minutes late and was told that plates come out as they are made. We then asked the manager separately and was once again given a lecture on how their dishes comes as their made, later to find out that the waiter never fired the dish.  Their problem was passed off as ours, a big no no in service- particularly as a "new" restaurant. After all the problems with the timing of our meal no one else even came over to apologize or explain.  It would not have been that difficult for the GM to stop by and provide an explanation and apology for the mishap (needless to say it ruined our experience).  I really wanted to like the new Fog City but I think the management should take note of the recent reviews (many 1 star from what I can see), and pay closer attention to what their customers want.  Secondly, I think there's a huge opportunity for them to improve their level of service. Patrons don't dine out to get schooled on how things work- just make great food and deliver good service. Recognize when things aren't going right, and make them right- it's not that difficult.  Lastly, they should seriously consider adding a few of the classic Fog City Diner items back on the menu.

rySp7MIdFZxUqtQd4NQjfA.review_text: I ordered the saigon dip which I found to be very tasty and regular iced tea which was so delicious that I had several glasses!

xLMRzWiStf2CfqXUQcTAKQ.review_text: 3 types of beets in a yummy sauce, really well garnished and tasty deviled eggs, and crisp/warm fries with bonito flakes. The only minor disappointment was the bonito flakes were not moving.  Check out this video:  youtu.be/jbuFRpNP9Zk.  That's what bonito flakes are supposed to do. Great view of the bay. Good waterfront location.

fitXjNnwVB_HzqaBSrIGXQ.review_text: Good spot near embarcadero for drinks and food. It feels upscale and modern but is also casual. Staff is friendly and seating is easy.   I recommend the pork sandwich with pho broth dipping sauce -- a clever take on the french dip. The bread is also excellent here to get on the side. It is served perfectly warm with warmed butter

ZImbLO2ElLmOyBgLefvANw.review_text: Definitely not the place it used to be. Inexperienced hostesses seating others before your reservation. Menu is blah! Because we were never seated we went to Gott's which is a much better choice! Definitely not a representation of the Bay Area like it used to be. What a shame!

bMwiNmSeYfTkzQ_eViDZDg.review_text: Summary: convenient location across from Pier 23, warm modern interiors and excellent service almost make up for the mediocre food  Walking along the Embarcadero is one of my favorite date activities, and I've passed Fog City many a time. When a friend took me out for a belated birthday lunch, we decided to go here to cross it off my list. We shared the much-regaled Deviled Eggs: the crispy bacon bits were delightful, but it was still just a deviled egg at the end of the day.   I got the burger (had been craving a gourmet burger since NOT ordering it at NOPA a few days earlier) and asked for furikake fries, in place of the regular side. The melty American cheese was a major throwback to Mickey D days and childhood. Although the wood-fired grill in the back is quite impressive, my burger wasn't quite as smokey as I would have liked. I appreciated the generously thick patty, but I wish it had actually been smaller, since it made the lettuce, onion, and tomato toppings feel unproportional. Couldn't finish it all.  My friend got the smoked salmon dish. Although quite pricey (close to $20?) for 2 slices of rye bread with toppings, the smoked salmon was one of the best I've enjoyed. I hate overly salty smoked fish! But this smoked salmon was definitely not too salty, and it had a fresh flavor that almost tasted like sashimi. It was beautifully garnished with microgreens, dill fronds, and creamy avocado and plated against a dark contrast. I probably wouldn't pay that much for that little food myself, but I enjoyed a taste of her selection.  Overall, if I want somewhere to take a break while walking along the Embarcadero again, I might stop by to catch a game at the bar or a quick bite at the cute tables outside. But definitely not a destination meal in the future. Big shout-out to the wait staff who kept our glasses filled but never made us feel bothered or fawned over.

hR38WUHHvXH32mDo21vVpA.review_text: We went down to Fog City because my old man knows one of the bartenders there who had previously worked at Picco in Larkspur. I don't generally need an excuse to go to a restaurant, but the promise of great cocktails is as good a reason as any.  We had a couple rounds at the bar since we arrived well before our reservation time. They have a great list of specialty cocktails, including the Goslings-based dark n' slush which was the hit of the group. We had the brussels sprouts and deviled eggs at the bar, and both were excellent. The brussels sprouts were a little bit seared on the outside and mixed with asian pear, which I didn't expect to like but it was awesome. The deviled eggs were sprinkled with crispy quinoa which was new and delightful. I love deviled eggs, and these were some of the best.  At the table, the 6 of us shared a few of the big plates. The chilled dill cucumber pickles were fresh and light, the fries were of course fantastic, and the wood oven whole chicken was very good. Light on the seasoning but cooked to perfection, only Zuni Cafe's chicken can rival Fog City.

xcYoof7zW_uxtNt5WR6d0Q.review_text: A SF landmark and worth a visit. Recent remodel and new menu is delicious with interesting fusion of flavors. Small plate lunch menu - esp. crab cakes were perfectly done and just enough.

iK0CPqlRoogwULySPkr1nw.review_text: While walking down the Embarcadero trying to meet up with another couple around 5pm, my girlfriend and I decided to stop in here for a quick drink and snack.  We were seated immediately and a waiter came for a drink order within minutes.  The decor was very modern and aesthetically pleasing.  Overall a nice vibe.  I must say, the house cocktails were AMAZING!  Innovative ingredients that do not seem at home in a glass come together to create something wondrous.  I would try them all in one sitting if I could.  The beer list had some that I had never heard of before.  One of the servers (who I am assuming is also the head chef from his demeanor) suggested the IPA.  Good suggestion!  I personally hate IPAs with a passion, but I found this one to be surprisingly tasty.  I believe that it was called the Denogginizer.  Even the non-alcoholic cocktails were spectacular.  The service was above average.  Our original waiter took over 10 minutes after the second half of our party sat down to take new drink orders, but the head chef who brought out the food and other drinks was very fast while still being extremely engaging and funny.  While watching him it looked like he brought the food out to every table and chatted with the patrons!  We did not eat much as we were headed down to the Ghirardelli factory, but I wanted a snack and settled on the Kale salad.  It had very soft leaves and fresh fruit, but I was not overly impressed and did not eat very much of the salad.  This had nothing to do with the quality or preparation of the food, but more with my specific cravings at the time.  The chef immediately noticed the unfinished salad and removed it from the table.  Disregarding my insistence that I was not dissatisfied with the salad or the restaurant, the chef removed the salad from the tab.  It was easy to see that he took pride in his work and did not want his customers to have a bad experience.    Overall, I highly recommend coming here for the drinks.  I am planning on stopping by every time that I am in SF.  It is a bit on the expensive side (as is most of the city), but worth every penny.

X9O3zjSjwvckR8Rayo2NqA.review_text: I liked Fog City Diner and I like this updated "Fog City" The drinks are yummy and the food tasty. I like the remodel , the bar is spacious and has a great view. All the men working there are friendly and HANDSOME

YhgKBemOaY0hNtITK9t7MA.review_text: Loved the old Fog City Diner.  It was very kid friendly and the kids loved it.   Why couldn't they just let it be?  As a family  walked into the new joint .. looked around... glimpsed a menu and quickly walked out again.  So sad.  Still the kids had fun in the near-bye fountains at Levis Plaza.

1MdLAfawu8HxT_dCahpMyg.review_text: We tried almost all the apps & desserts: dungeoness crab special, Mac n cheese, cheeseburger, fries, Brussel sprouts, beets, bread pudding, doughnuts. Two items stood out as fantastic - specifically the crab and Brussel sprouts. Best I've ever had on both. The crab was served cleaned and halved, oven baked with chili butter. It was fresh (we were told it was alive 3 hours prior) and immaculately prepared. One order per 2 people for $30 - well worth it. Whatever the Brussels were prepared in was so flavorful and they were charred well. There was some kind of pear or Apple chunks mixed in which were unnecessary.  The Mac n cheese was great. The fries were meh as were the doughnuts. The beets were good but the goat cheese water that they sat in wasn't the best.  The service was decent but we had to ask several times for dishes to be cleared.  I had the Vodka fix which was delicious but tiny. The wines came with a healthy pour. I would eat here again and try other items.

PE7dvRNZGvbOQyVXCukQYw.review_text: I LOVE this place! I first came here for dinner a month ago and was blown away. Had their Milk Punch drink and it was lemony and so good! The deviled eggs with sprinkles of bacon were a dream come true! The Veggies, especially the brussel sprouts, were just amazing. No one does veggies like these guys. The Chicken was truly mind-blowing. You must order the whole chicken!!! There was special salt you sprinkle on top that comes with it that I went crazy for. The frozen coffee granita with vanilla ice cream was a dream come true. Loved it so much I went back a 2nd time. A top new favorite.

ZlJtLWqVeQ5sTfIUr7FwIw.review_text: Food was quite good. Service was off for our table. Wine served with Ice in the glass.  Really? Scotch served instead of Bourbon. Not a kid friendly restaurant. We asked if they had a kids menu and they blurted out NO.  Can you make some pasta with butter?  NO. Restaurant remodel looks great, Now work on service and menu please. Please use the $500 dollars we dropped for dinner for 8 to improve the service.

0JfJYZT6vPKsXi5NaQSCeQ.review_text: Was down at a reception @ Tcho (5 star choco) last night with GF and some foodies...all agreed: top notch food, service and the new decor is super.  Will be back soon for sure.

DNAxM8v3BaJuSOx6X2vibQ.review_text: Food was ok....for the price umm not so much. Maybe Im spoiled because I live in the Napa Valley but I come to the City quite often and always find great food but was highly dissatisfied with my order.  Clams were good but they were nothing to rant and rave about...fries okay...oh the bread was good...Brussel sprouts yummy but needed something...oh yea oysters were the bomb, but you'd be an idiot to screw those up. My BF enjoyed the clams though if that helps.

thtQHcBilE8wwVQFbLp40w.review_text: Great atmosphere Great people.  Food was VERY good but not great.  I WOULD go back because the place is cool,,,,  I might not plan a full dinner here.

IUBTHEaCm-1xcv1lT99eWw.review_text: I went on a double-date here on Friday, October 28 and had a wonderful experience. I had never actually been to the old Fog City Diner before so had nothing stuck in my mind to compare it to. It seems that a lot of the other reviewers are hung up on the old Fog City Diner and having a hard time accepting that it's a completely new restaurant which is a shame for them.  They layout of the restaurant is very open so even though it was a very busy Friday night with a packed bar as well it never felt crowded. They have comfortable booths and an open kitchen with a big wood-fire oven and the overall aesthetic of the restaurant is modern but warm. The one thing I didn't get about the decor was the weird spaceman by the bathroom, that seemed out of place to me but not a big deal.   The most important part of our experience was the delicious food and cocktails. We were pretty hungry on Friday evening and definitely made sure we got a solid sampling of their unique menu. Highlights that I recommend you don't miss out on on the food side for me were the deviled eggs, the pork cheeks plate and the clams dish.  We also went a little crazy on the desserts which might have been the best part of the meal. The home-cooked crullers, frozen custard, and Panna Cotta were all so delicious and the perfect exclamation mark on a well-rounded delicious meal.  One final thought, make sure you try the Fog City Milk Punch cocktail. I had no idea what to expect based on all of the ingredients (bourbon, rum, brandy, citrus, milk, etc..) but it a delicious sweet drink that also packed a good punch. Overall, the new Fog City hits it out of the park in all aspects and I can't wait to go back!

y3pgJ3fImo4F1pB_im_ncw.review_text: This place is a venture back to the not too distant SF past. Pre tech boom, pre dot-com bust/boom, back in the days when a policeman would grab a ruffian with a crookedly knotted skinny necktie and gutterly threaten, "go back south of Market." Despite its remodel and appearance of a modern restaurant, its clientele has a definite old school SF vibe to it; this is good people watching when you get tired of looking at recent SF residents.  Like: Furikake fries. Don't you take my crumbs! Roasted baby carrots, cauliflower nuggets, and grilled asparagus; they do veggies well.  Dessert, frozen custard on cruller with a side of caramelly marshmallowy sauce.   Dislike: My entree was a rib dish that was taken off the menu a few days later. Edible, but overcooked and forgettable. I'm glad Fog City decided to forget it as well.  Hit or miss: Ahi tartare. The ahi was fresh and flavorful, but the rice cake was in-between chewy and crispy.  Go because you or your guests are conservative and a little old school, but still want to try a modern menu without going full do-you-know-who-harvested-this-oyster-locavore. Go because you want to see local newscasters on break. Go because it's not difficult to get a seat and it's a comfortable spot to enjoy the company of friends. If I could give 1/2 stars (Yelp, please!), it would be 3.5 stars.

lCSTCU07HcyHpGKbnQGUIA.review_text: Here's a couple of personal opinions of dishes I've tried at Fog City.  Grilled Local Calamari - Good. Nothing really wow-d me compared to other places Deviled Eggs- Great touch with the bacon. Bacon makes everything 10x better! Brussels Sprouts- YUM, I'm never usually a fan but this is delicious. Handcut Furikake Fries- My must get starter every time I dine. YUMMY  Smoked Salmon Sandwich- I ended up just picking the salmon off and leaving the greens and bread. OK Saigon Dip Sandwich-Sounds good on the menu, but just mediocre Fog City Burger and Fries- Good, your average burger Sesame Chicken Salad- Overall my favorite! Very flavorful and I'm not a big salad person. YUMMY. There was tons of flavor in every bite.  Will definitely dine there again soon.

grQfs3DN2CHgzphRXssgCA.review_text: Great revamped menu and cocktail list. Menu was a bit too small for me for brunch/lunch but it tasted great, trendy and more importantly worth every penny.

LgpqJITXdSAfGq88R4YeKQ.review_text: WOW This place had some yummy food.  However the prices are high and the portions can get small depending on the dish.  Many are shareable/topas type items but they do have some good entree items.  The staff is nice and helpful. They can get packed so be aware at peak times.  Its a good location but you have to come around from the back side.

vbXmCVj1RZ4civT7nrcKyw.review_text: Returned recently as I had been telling a friend about the best Bourbon signature cocktail in the City, The Milk Punch.  It did not disappoint and my guest who fancies themselves as a bourbon expert was impressed with my choice.  We opened with the fries, cauliflower, and oysters.  For two people it was quite a bit but we will have to come back with more people and try the rest of the appetizer menu.    For entrees we went with the pork chop and octopus.  We barely ate half of each.  The octopus was probably the best I've had.  It wasn't tough and it was prepared over a bean based bed that quite tasty.  I had the other signature drink, The Mule, which was also quite tasty and came in a copper cup which kept it clean and cold tasting!  We cleared our palates with a frozen Affogato.  Definitely a great follow up to my first visit with lots of parking around.  We walked off our meal with a nice walk along the Embarcadero.

0hR3xOT9RezseuDj-VZ0aA.review_text: Royal New Years Day DISAPPOINTMENT!  Sadly right from the walk in a totoal bummer.   We arrived at 5 looking to sit 7 and they said "sure" but they don't open until 5:30 (fine we'll wait)...oh no, sorry we have a reservation coming in at 7:15.   "if you could eat and be out of here we'll seat you"...hummm, ya that's how a reservation works people.   If you can feed us in an hour & half we'll be out.  We ordered cocktails (the gal at the bar...SO RUDE, REALLY SWEET HEART? YOUR NOT AT SUR...TAKE A BREAK AND MANAGE MY MANHATTAN IN UNDER 15 MINUTES..NEVER ONCE ASKED IF WE WANTED ANOTHER, JOKE.)  and the children has sodas, sitting at a side table.   The man at the desk was HOUNDING THE KIDS to move because they had a 5:30 reservation coming...we told him they will move at 5:30 as we are sitting at that time too.   At 5:01 the front desk man to leave, they needed the table.   THE ENTIRE RESTAURANT WAS EMPTY!   We asked the kids to stand by the door until our we sat down...2 minutes later.   Mind you...that table didn't have a soul sitting there for 20 minutes.  THEY NEED TO CHILL.  The dinner menu was a train wreck...plates to share "WHAT DOES THAT MEAN". I believe when something is to "Share" it's large enough for 2-3 guests.   Not even close...it was a 20 minutes dissertation from the waitress about what is big enough for 2+ and what was really for one, HUH?,   Clearly, our table was ordering traditional: salads, burgers for the kids with fries, carrots.     The adults were battling over how much was enough for 4 people...MAJOR HEADACHE.    Turned out that the burger is a standard flat burger, no possible way it would feed more than one (cutting it into four doesn't make it feed more.  Make a huge burger and that would make sense)...no sides on any entree.     Then to cap it off, there was a a first wave of food then 30 minutes later another wave of food and then the final wave because the portions were just random.   All the portions were for one...other than the chicken.  The food was good and although it was way more work than it was worth it tasted very good.  I have to say the staff (NOT THE BAR STAFF...BUGGERS) was friendly and very nice, however, it really seemed disorganized and unprofessional.   SIDE NOTE: BRUSSEL SPROUTS...AMAZING!

Q0_r1PdCIXwopvdppGAoJA.review_text: On January 06, 2015, we were in a party of five who had spent the day site seeing and having a great time. We ended the evening late at Frog City, San Francisco, CA. Everything was just great.   The atmosphere was so relaxed and so beautiful. There were a lot of people there and they all seemed to be enjoying the evening too.   The waiter was so nice, thoughtful and was very eager to please us. We thoroughly enjoyed our meal and I have to say we all were very impressed. Three of us had a hamburger and I have to say it was the best I have ever had!   Hopefully, we will be able to return there again when we are visiting in the area.

lBgPXxUwdzUz7YJkykeccA.review_text: Fog city memo:  Very impressive location and decoration.  But in the end it is a failure in quality and price.   Service is very professional but it is a disappointment because of the food.   I order the crispy cheddar biscuit bites. Very dry and to me seems like it is a day old.   The ribeye. Ah. Good beef should not need a strong sauce. So either the beef is of low quality or not well seasoned.  But in the end the sauce on the rib eye is very very salty.  If you eat the rib eye without the sauce it is much better and tastes fine.    Finally the dessert.  The B bomb. Was recommend by server which like said professional and also polite. The donut cruller was crispy and fluffy.  The custer ice cream creamy and sweet.  The caramel sauce perfect.    However in the end Im just disappointed my meal was still over $80 for 3 courses and I am a single diner.  Base on the customers all tourists with no insight.   They spend a great deal of money on the decor but should spend more time on the food.

cml12ZWtr4m8YejBjPE70A.review_text: Service was good and food was just OK. All the fun, cool vibe of the old Fog City Diner is gone though.

DKqE9GDvkji_0MOT6_NjJw.review_text: Too expensive   Super long wait.  Mediocre food.  Akward staff and bridge and tunnel clientele.  Cramped seating.  Not a super duper place.

eGs6GlsMG9hTRVnYyEk16Q.review_text: I work in the awkward space of Telegraph Hill, and new food options are hard to come by. Fog City is a place I've been meaning to try for a while, so I made a reservation for a work lunch. The food here is not bad and probably worthy of 4 stars, but the service and steep prices knock off one star for me.  The ambience is very trendy, with almost exclusively dim, natural lighting and dark wood textures. The water cups are encircled with "Fog City" around the base. It is quite loud in here for a more upscale restaurant, so maybe not the best place for a professional lunch.  I got the Smoked Salmon Smorrebrod ($17), which I still don't know how to pronounce. It's an open-face sandwich of smoked salmon, egg salad, avocado, peppers, and a generous garnish of herbs on top. Again, I do think the food here is quite tasty, and I really loved the sharp, spicy kick of the peppers. The ingredients are fresh and beautifully arranged. Both of our sandwiches came on casually-uniquely-shaped wooden slabs, because porcelain plates are for the mainstream.  The service here is quite slow and inattentive, except for the kind people refilling the water. I had to ask for the waiter multiple times to take our order and deal with the check. We were able to finish our meal in under an hour, so it wasn't entirely awful, but I did feel a bit hysterical constantly trying to flag someone down. It was pretty busy for lunch, so I would recommend making a reservation!

JhvfYiqOhQ52RUmlBrMe6A.review_text: Have to admit, avoided this place in the past; thought it was a tourist trap. The food is amazing (if you need proof, read my recent reviews of other places---I can be a tough critic). Loved our waiter, Tobias, and loved the tapas style!! Can't say enough about the quality of the food--EVERYTHING we tried was delicious! The vegan and the carnivore were satisfied! An impressive, albeit small, wine list---and up to date! Can't wait to become a regular! Top 5 in SF (from a serious foodie)!

Wgs8ozAIgULSaiGNQmCkzg.review_text: My gf's and I weren't sure what to expect but were pleasantly surprised. The wait staff was extremely attentive and made wonderful suggestions. The deviled eggs, fig salad, pole beans, chicken and apple crisp were all delicious. The menu doesn't dazzle when figuring out what to order. Its basically an American menu but the food had a pow to it when it was placed in front of us. I was really impressed how they jazzed up all American favorites.

Kr9sA9gKISX5i8WN4_nXcQ.review_text: It's totally different than what it used to be, but it's really nice and has a good vibe. Had their fog city burger and it was pretty tasty and we ordered a couple desserts and they were really good. They made really good moscow mules...and word is that their bar tenders are really good...Great location too!!

tcXbDFbFKrEA3Bks_zAm0Q.review_text: I really liked this place. I like the cool fun vibe inside with the row of seats along a curved big window to the Embarcadero and a bar down the middle. Service was friendly and on par. I liked ordering several small courses with option to have a bigger meal if you wanted. We Tried the deviled eggs with crunchy quinoa and crispy bacon and those flavors and textures worked well- YUM! The Oysters were the best we've had in long while. Highly recommend! The made to order Doughnuts were pretty good. I got the chocolate ones and the chocolate was very good- none of that fake milk chocolate stuff. Oh and you can't go wrong with the frozen custard!

WecuAsHBDZGj7Z6_sJcQAw.review_text: Clear as day.  Food is delicious: Open-faced smoked salmon and egg salad sandwich with avocado and herbs. Brussels sprouts with pear cubes and ponzu coating. Loved both.  Prices are high: $16 for the sandwich was excessive. $7 for the sprouts reasonable. This was a business lunch happy to not be paying for.  Service was opportunistic: Didn't feel entirely welcomed and almost a burden when still deciding. Too bad as the iconic waterfront and open fire space was otherwise endearing.  It's a super clear three stars.

KkBCkxguivHRIjT1h55x2w.review_text: $17 Chicken Noodle Soup.  Seriously it is a tourist trap sad the old place went away.

QlZRh-SbAf1Onj_tgBlmYg.review_text: Beautiful meal. We had the ribs and the whole chicken. The chicken was maybe the best chicken I've ever had in my life. Deboned. Moist and flavorful. Came with a side of lemon and spices to season it further.   I went back a week late to have the chicken again.  The remodel makes it much more modern while still being a SF classic. :)

tFAtaH_vfcGn447uVZdTDw.review_text: Great burger here and love the wood fired oven! Unfortunately we happen to be here on Sunday afternoon so no wood fired Chicken. Have to go back! Our server was the best. Skip the wings, not worth $13. Didn't read the menu and thought the wings would be "interesting". Not so. For lunch can't go wrong with the burger and fries. Next time trying the hot brown:) nice decor too

GcYfUzBRH6RIDEyZjDWMhg.review_text: The new fog city is absolutely fantastic!  The only complaint i have is they measure their damn pours....seriously, if you charge me $17 for a drink-FREE POUR that shit.  Otherwise, the food is fantastic, we had the cauliflower nuggets, tuna, deviled eggs, the rib eye, and chicken and everything was delicious.  The chicken is probably the best ive ever had!!!   5 stars for cuisine and service 3 stars for overpriced and under poured drinks.

PB_ZE9viuWvFS6JJ-tcLSQ.review_text: Great experience!  The waiter was fantastic, the food all unique and flavorful.   Definitely recommend it.

RTbTGW5QVsYVRWrPFWe7KA.review_text: Saigon dip was phenomenal, very cool sandwich.

djxnI8Ux8ZYQJhiOQkrRhA.review_text: You had me at cheeseburger, Fog City. You had me at cheeseburger.  It's not often that I encounter a patty with homemade American cheese. It's just the right amount of melty on top of a thin yet flavorful piece of meat. A simple bun brings it all together. Give or take the pickles, they're good, I just like my burger with cheese.  There are plenty of other items on the menu to consider in case you're not into cheeseburgers. Deviled eggs, seasonal salad, fresh oysters. You've heard the term American (New), yes? Not to mention milk punch and a list of classic cocktails that well executed.  Did I mention that they serve custard? Really, really good custard. That's coming from a St. Louis gal, too. It's no Ted Drewes, but I don't think Fog City is trying to make concretes here. It's just rich delicious custard.  What's old is new in San Francisco, and Fog City is the perfect example of a classic diner that's taken their operation to the new level. I love it!  ***Note: I was invited to a special lunch with complimentary bites, but returned on my own a few weeks later for dinner. Yes, I liked it that much!***

e6OwRdPgmjx3R-HCgAN1-w.review_text: Used to go here when it was the old charming little diner.  Tried to go here before a show at the America's Cup Pavilion last Saturday.  Was turned away at the door.  Exchange was as follows:  Bouncer:  You guys have a reservation? Me:  No, we just want to grab a drink at the bar. Bouncer:  Bar is all full. Me:  It looks like there's plenty of standing room. Bouncer:  We don't do that here. Me:  Do what? Allow people to stand at a bar?  Bouncer:  Yeah.  Errr, WTF.  Okay.  So this bar operates entirely different than EVERY OTHER BAR IN THE WORLD.  Awesome.  Took my business to the Waiheke Island Yacht Club where we were graciously greeted and provided drinks at the bar that was STANDING ROOM ONLY at the time.  Way to make a (second) first impression Fog City.

HorQ90eiUPfnesQlIraaJA.review_text: We went for brunch with some friends in from out of town. This is a great spot for a classy last minute Sunday brunch when all the super cool spots are already booked or don't take reservations (I'm talking to you Foreign Cinema and Plow)  It is definitely pricy - one of my friends got the $17 chicken soup - CHICKEN SOUP for SEVENTEEN DOLLARS - WTF?!  He said it was good, but I dunno how good it could possibly have been.  I ordered the Hot brown sandwich, I have never had one, but have seen it in many travel shows about Kentucky and they are supposed to be fantastic. This was indeed a damn fine sammy, the bacon was super smokey and the sauce was like crack sauce.  Order it and thank me later.   We ordered  doughnuts as a starter (2 doughnuts to an order) and they were good, but I gotta say if I order doughnuts in a restaurant, they better come out piping hot (at the very least warm) out of the fryer - these were good, but room temp, so you can skip it, as tempting as they sound.    The views would have been amazing if there wasn't construction netting blocking the bay views.

dWe4qfWT_urGY8spxucAUg.review_text: I was staying nearby and me, myself and I stopped by for lunch...decided to have it at the bar.  The bartender was very courteous and nice.  I ordered the Asian chicken salad and it was so bad, that I had to return it...and I have never done that...it was drenched on a bitter dressing and the chicken had been cut up with fat, bones and tendons so when I munched on these one too many times, I had to stop and send it back.  The good news is that the nice bartender immediately addressed the situation and took it back without a problem.  The manager promptly stopped by to check on me and the situation, which I appreciated.  I traded the salad for some deviled eggs and a couple of slices of their scrumptious bread ($3.00!) and that was a decent experience.  My take is that this place is pretty $$$ for the quality, although the place is pretty cool with a good location.

G-8BH0Zxu7zQebp3_3QqTA.review_text: Not impressed. The only people daft enough to come here thinking they'll have a great experience are tourists. The food is overpriced and not very good and the drinks were anything but artisan. Even at lower prices I couldn't justify coming here given the taste of the food and the subpar drinks.  On top of all of this I came back later and sat outside to use my laptop real fast and they came out and told me outdoor seating was for customers only. There were 10 separate tables three of which were being sat in and they are telling me I should move because it's for clients only???  It's one thing to boot me out because they actually need the table, it's another to tell me to bug off because I didn't order a $15 sandwich.  Will not return and will recommend against.

NDW7SjtgMTzwuZSWpq7i7g.review_text: Good food, great service. We happened upon this place as we walked to our car. We were surprised by the price (we went in for lunch) but definitely a good place for dinner!

y_4Dq1MCwbsTOEgbaoMQXA.review_text: I came to Fog City a couple of years ago, because the place looked cute, so we decided to try it for dinner... And the hanger steak here was amazing! The meat was so tender and juicy... perfectly flavored. The Clam chowder was OK, nothing special. All I keep remembering from this place is the hanger steak. Recently, I returned to Fog City in hopes of eating another hanger steak, but they took it off the menu... Why!?!? And the food this last time around was really mediocre and unmemorable... Therefore they get 3 stars overall.

1qkGK9cDxuoD_Og_68WI-A.review_text: I write this review as a professional in the food industry. This was one of the worst dining experiences in San Francisco I have ever had! First the noise was unbelievable even after being placed in one of their more quieter sections.  It took us a half hour to get someones attention and over half hour until we ate:  the five of us got our meals five to 10 minutes apart,  The bread served was so tough that we laughed while we tugged on it because it was not cut through. Three of the dishes were way over salted and one was totally unedible. Staff was also unprofessional in ways.

Dc1bruuyBZaHSthOaEM6PA.review_text: Having been a regular saturday diner at the former restaurant, I was excited to try the newly re-opened restaurant.   Liked the new layout and decor (though honestly the restaurant could be any new SF place now, its lost its special charm).   Sat at the bar and was addressed by the hipster bartender as "Cheif, Dude and Buddy", had a burger for $14 (it came with a plate) and then realized i'd have to order a side (fries) for $6, so I had a $20 burger (it was good), a cocktail and so-so service.   Would I go back or again be the regular I used to be, well...no.  I would go back if I was in the mood but now Fog City is the same as every other precious new restaurant in SF...sadly

H4HPzkK0pCJ3vQqZccPrag.review_text: I went to the new and improved Fog City Saturday night and had a great time! They were busy and service subsequently was less attentive, but that's ok in my book.   We had the deviled eggs and the fries to start out with, so yummy! We shared the lobster. Ummm I think it was still moving when it came out? Antenae and everything left intact, but it was good!   The Milk Punch and the Monkey Fighter were amazing drinks. Definitely a must try!

9X_NhC9TKsPj1Yi41jRYAA.review_text: This has to be one of my top 3 spots.  Best Brussle Srouts EVER.  I am not joking.  This is 90% of the reason I go out of my way to come here.  The other 10% is the ambiance and decor.  Simple, clean and comfortable yet slightly upscale.  This is a comfortable spot to bring out of town guests since it is not over crowded or funky.

OqDL7gioC9qLuY66HdtHJw.review_text: This was a fantastic experience!  Based on a recommendation we stopped here for the Grilled Spiced Lamb Skewers - which were phenomenal!  Also the Pickled Gulf Shrimp is almost as good.  We had fantastic service at the bar - due to Dustin (who l also learned is in charge of the awesome menu)  despite his lack of help behind the bar that night.  I was thoroughly impressed with the professionalism and food quality and will make sure to come back whenever I am in SF!

53glsY-cD-PrDdNmkJQSXA.review_text: I don't really remember much about this place before the re-design, it has been years, so I'm not going to compare it to what it use to be.  Came in for an early dinner, almost empty, we were greeted and sat immediately.  Overall I will say the service was very good.  Our waitress was nice, but she kept over compensating for everything and tried to tell us how to eat the dishes, which is usually pretty self-explanatory.  Order: Fried Artichokes Brocollini w/ Garlic Lamb Kebabs (2) People  The fried artichokes were presented nicely and very tasty with the aioli dipping sauce.  Nice seasoning and plenty of "flesh" to eat.  The whole thing wasn't edible but most was crispy enough to eat.  The Brocollini was delicious and actually was my favorite part.  The Lamb Kebabs were under-whelming and there really wasn't any care in presentation.  it reminds me of when I make tacos at home and just slice up a tomato, some onions and cilantro and have it all out to put together.  It was just a place with two kebabs and sliced onion and tomatoes, to me if you are going to charge $19-$22 or whatever it was, there should be something to it.  The dish was served with lettuce leaves and we were then told how to put everything in it and eat it.....  anyway.  Also, one of my biggest pet peeves was the time between the vegetable coming out and the entre, about 10-15 minutes.  I want to eat my veggie with my protein, not as a separate course.  Overall it was a nice night out, but honestly, I just don't see the value.  I am use to over-priced Napa, but at least with Napa the menu items are fairly unique, so if I'm dropping $12 on an app, $8 on a veggie and $20+ on an entre it's usually worth the money.  I won't go out of my way to go back, but I'm sure there are some items they do very well, some of the other stuff coming out looked tasty.

xsq_bpGYLoPpuzUTDbifDw.review_text: Not bad.  Had the calamari and a burger.  The former was pretty good while the latter was so-so.  The servers were nice and fairly prompt, although not quite as attentive as we would have liked, considering it was sparsely populated for most of our meal.

XQ-kvSPLSBPiivNpt9GyuQ.review_text: Our party of four initially tried to get into Hillstone just down the street on a busy Saturday night but the wait was over an hour and a half.  We all joked that was the best thing to happen to us because Fog City was the only thing we could talk about for the next week. It was THAT good!  Friends asked what kind of place it was... I guess one would describe it as a contemporary upscale diner?  The place is super cute, equipped with a wood-fired over and large grill that serve as the centerpieces.  For starters we went with Hand-cut Furikake Fries with Garlic Aioli. The white sauce for dipping was heaven (not sure on name).  We also ordered four Chilled Local Oysters served with a barrel-aged hot sauce, shallots, mignonette and parsley. They were so good we ordered another round of 4. One of our guests said he'd just eat these all night. (see pic)  The Brussels Sprouts with Asian Pears (we originally ordered Broccoli, but they ended up bringing out these). The brussel sprouts were a nice surprise. Although we had these at Delfina the night before, the pears sent these over the top.  The Oven Roasted Baby Carrots was the other veggies we ordered. They were a touch on the sweet side and were served with a black garlic mole, almonds, and cotija cheese. The garlic mole sauce was super unique and a fresh approach.  The Fog City Burger was kind of lost in the shuffle with all of the food we got. House-made Bun, smoked tomato aioli, F.C. american cheese, tomato, onion bread & butter pickles. One of us ordered it as well done but it came out medium rare. I was happy with that though. hehe Extremely tasty!  Their signature Wood Oven Chicken was absolutely beautiful. Accompanied by charred brentwood corn, crispy potatoes and spiced maldon salt, the chicken could easily serve two people. Soooooooo good! (see pic)  Saving the best for last was the Berkshire Pork Cheeks served on a bed of bacon braised romano beans, hatch chilies, broccoli, and soft polenta. That pork cheeks was some of the best pork I've ever had in my entire life - It was so succulent that you didn't even need a fork to separate it. Each bite deserved a fork-full of each component on the dish, not just the meat. The polenta and the red sauce (name?) was the clincher. Whenever I head back up to San Francisco, it's this dish that I'll be craving!  The only letdown of the evening was the Grilled Beef Tongue with Chanterelle mushrooms, roasted turnips, mustard greens, and bacon vinaigrette. It was best described as a salad with a few bits of beef tongue. Everyone at the table tried it, but no one went back to it.  You know you loved your meal when you can't stop talking about it... Fog city - we'll be back!

hWmOlKKyLWHVsYxVoRAgHg.review_text: Our waiter was excellent, along with crab cakes, and grilled calamari with deep fried zuchini blossoms and red pepper.  These three alone deserves 4 stars.  However, i'm knocking down a star because of the smaller than small oysters and the cocktail wasn't strong enough for my taste. We were there normal happy hour time, but I don't think they even offer happy hour specials.  Imagine my sticker shock when we got the bill.

REWjbYaUkmGw04lNZraeQA.review_text: I came here for lunch with a few coworkers and had one of the best fried chicken sandwich of my life. My understanding is that the menu is always changing so if the friend chicken sandwich is on the menu, don't hesitate and just order it. The chicken is tender, juicy, well-seasoned, and fried perfectly, not oily at all. The coleslaw that topped the sandwich is super refreshing and is a great contrast to the fried chicken. End to end, service was excellent. We were seated quickly, and also got our menus, drinks, entrees, and check quickly as well. I would definitely come back for a fancy-ish lunch if I'm in the area. If you can, try to sit at the bar so you can see the kitchen in action - they put on quite a show.

kZe2CUs-9OeIViFa6QC0wA.review_text: I just had one of the best roast chickens I've ever had! We ordered that to share between two people, along with grilled broccoli rabe, bread, an IPA, and a glass of rose. Everything was fantastic. Given how hot it was tonight, we sat at one of the outdoor tables and got to enjoy eating al fresca under the trees. It was a perfect meal with good service, amazing food, great company, and hot weather to boot!

XOjhAsXxs-ChFLecUdyPNg.review_text: Fog City has the one of the best burgers in town.  It is on the expensive side however.  Always good service.

9Mc3mZX_Q8c6H_KjH8DZOQ.review_text: This place is a solid 4.5 stars but with the new renovation, it's a must for locals and tourists.   We ordered the deviled eggs, oysters, furikake fries (!), and jalepeno cocktails. I would order all of it again. Seriously considering it right now as it isn't THAT far from my desk.  Sit at the bar (on the side with a view of the bay), order yourself a cocktail, extra sauce for your furikake fries, and ignore the tourists' kids.

TQ-wfwEOs8yzer9t4wlKlg.review_text: Nice for out-of-towners and locals with views of the bay. I wish the  menu items did not remain the same for long periods of time.  The open fire dishes are certainly worth the try.  Friendly service and warm ambiance.

XdM2sxztF7JX6DZ6Qk4r9Q.review_text: I recall the old Fog City Diner fondly. Big-pour martinis and comfort food. Some days called for exactly that. So, I met a buddy here to see what they've done with the place...and the menu.  The first thing I noticed was the space. It seems a lot more open, spacious. We got our booth and checked out the menu. The list of six snacks at the top of the page looked great so we ordered all of them:  Chilled Dill Cucumber Pickles F.C. Ranch Cauliflower Nuggets Vadouvan Curry Serrano Chile Lime Deviled Eggs Crispy Quinoa Bacon Hand-cut Furikake Fries Garlic Aioli  Duchilly Hazelnuts Spanish Paprika Brussels Sprouts Asian Pears Ponzu.  Each of them was terrific...especially with a martini in my left hand. There was no way we were going to finish all of this so we did some damage and ordered a couple of dishes: Grilled Spiced Lamb Skewers with Tomato, Red Onion, Lemon, Vadouvan Yogurt, and Butter Lettuce Cups, Wood Oven Whole Chicken with Charred Brentwood Corn, Crispy Potatoes, and Spiced Maldon Salt.  Both of these were really good as well. The chicken was superb...only one step below the Zuni chicken perhaps.  The service was fine. Ambiance fine. Food very good. All in all a great return for a SF institution. Highly recommended...and fun.

FTfr7IJurqo_Ika3NoZ-Kw.review_text: After the whole Yelp thingamajig, I found myself situated here again with my good friends Jim and Isabella. All I can say is that the second time around was definitely a homerun/touchdown/goal/flyingelbowdrop/whathaveyou­.  One of the finest meals I've had in a long time. Every plate was prepared incredibly well. Favorites had to be the whole, de-boned chicken and the Brussels sprouts.   I mean, the Yelp event had great food, but I really wasn't expecting this level of execution. I really do hope that my subsequent visits will be just as memorable, but as for now, Fog City is a nickel in my book.

GeqXRhY8XBLEDU15Tm1LNg.review_text: One of the best burgers I've ever had.  Also had the lamb skewers.  Pretty good but I will have to get the burger again.  Solid how you can make it a double.

x_bpi_SRk-UNQ6-gfNJqnA.review_text: Best Chicken in the city! Cocktails refreshing too, everything else is OK.  Came here with Pia C. and Trisha M. as she was in town and we needed major catch up.
