Food: +Milk Punch- refreshing cocktail that tastes nothing like milk -Warm Country Style bread- large portion but not that exciting, or warm + Brussel Spouts- large bowl of well-seasoned brussel sprouts; order again +Eggplant Babagounus- over ordered here but this was as standard, non-stand-out appetizer -Ahi Tuna Tartar- too salty!!! i like the bite-sized servings though +Crab Cakes- delicious; only 2 pieces though; would order again +Wood Oven Whole Chicken- takes 30 minutes to prep so brace yourself. soft tender and juicy with potatos in the juice -Panna Cotta Pudding Cake- fail; we didn't enjoy it as much as we liked  Service: Made reservations and it wasn't too busy on  Thursday evening around 6:30.   Ambiance: Very alive and chatty after work; great place to get away from the dying financial district and closer to the calm  -Hungry Hungry Pongy

Fd7sClkueyyzfgV1QCS-9w.review_text: This place is good. Had the Benedict and I have no complaints. The deviled eggs were delicious and one even came on the bloody Mary. It took them awhile to take our order even though the place was empty which of why I didn't give it 5 stars.

I-meqHrMad7Tkm4vXvjyyw.review_text: Meh. The food is decent. They made a big fuss about having more than 4 credit cards on a 12 person bill. Not such a great finish to a fair dinner experience.

lVrNac8ldvymVo6K8yHeWA.review_text: I'd say the newly renovated Fog City Diner is ascetically pleasing with great service BUT that comes at a high price.   The best dishes Fog City Diner offered were the selection of gourmet vegetable dishes. In particular the long stem broccoli and carrots. Those two dishes were lightly seasoned and had a dash of olive oil to make them flavorful as well as healthy.   Unfortunately while I was enjoying my vegetables, I realized I had to shout across the table to communicate with the rest of my party. At dinner time, be ready to project your voice. Also, I was curious what a $35 whole chicken would taste like. Must be at least seven times better than a $5 Costco chicken right?! Well...it was dry. I was surprised how expensive a dry chicken was.   Bottom line: Great vegetable dishes, loud inside, dry chicken, overpriced.

O4q8s3LBs4kjCcNJ9LkTLA.review_text: Your own private quarters along the wharf! Solid wood door, subway tile, dim mood lighting, 2 handlebars for traction control all within large private restroom make this the best place to drop a deuce in the whole entire city!!!

xLE1FUeiLg7Map9EDgU9fw.review_text: If a friend from out of town arrived seeking a restaurant recommendation, (the new) Fog City would not be on my list.     Two of us went there on Thursday, 24 October 2013, anticipating a wonderful experience based upon previously eating at the old Fog City Diner. We were met with a busy and noisy new environment. Within the first few moments, we ordered cocktails, one being a gin and tonic where two of the most popular gins in the world were not available - Bombay and Tanqueray.    Plowing on, we ordered wine and food.  The wine arrived soon - the drinks never arrived and we asked one to the managers to delete the drinks from the order.   Any sensitive restauranteur would have comped a desert or coffee - - - Fog City nothing.  One of the twists to the new restaurant, as specified on the menu, is plate sharing.  One problem: the proper utensils for the sharing of food (spoons, forks, etc.) were never provided prior to our asking.    Another issue was that for a tomato salad consisting of many delicious and small components, a spoon or cracker or baguette would have have been superior to incessant stabbing with a fork yielding minimal results.  The food was basically fine; however, while most restaurants provide some form of bread with which to soak up the sauces, not Fog City. No bread was ever provided.  After desert, the bill instantly appeared.  Guess what was on the bill? $25.50 of cocktails never received!  I called the waitress to inform her I was incensed to discover the cocktail charge and before I even got the words out of my mouth . . .  she knew far too quickly about the error in billing. Hmmm?   This comment of hers would lead a reasonable person to believe that perhaps alcohol-infused patrons might overlook careful scrutiny of their bill.  Thus, Fog City would be $25.50 richer and their patrons $25.50 poorer.  The only conclusion to be drawn is buyer beware.

S0Pji5ZPQwlolC7vlq1lug.review_text: I never got a chance to try Fog City Diner, but A & I were downtown, for once, and decided to make a day of it.   We walked from the Ferry Building to the restaurant (now just Fog City), which was actually a good walk. All the outdoor tables were occupied, but only a few indoor tables were occupied.   A used to frequent Fog City Diner on an almost daily basis years ago and he was telling me how they really opened up and streamlined the layout when they remodeled. I never saw it before, but I am loving the new open layout.  FOOD * Warm old fashioned sugar dusted doughnuts - Warm, doughy o's of goodness! Simple, yet delicious. * Deviled eggs with bacon and crispy quinoa - There is a definite crispy crunchiness which you would think comes from the bacon, but it's actually the crispy quinoa. I don't know who thought of sprinkling that on the eggs, but whoever it was is absolutely brilliant! Now I want to make crispy quinoa and sprinkle it in everything too! * Furikake fries - I think I pretty much love Furikake anything, but these fries were truly delicious. I'd go here just to have these again. * Fog City Burger - The beef was cooked perfectly medium rare. They cut it in half for us and the burger wasn't falling apart. The cheese really added to the flavor and I loved their special sauce. It also comes with a side of fries. Yes, more fries!!! Not Furikake, but still very good.  We were way too full for dessert, but there were several things on the menu that we would definitely come back to try.  PRICE About $50. for two including tax/tip, no drinks.  (Please excuse any errors. This review was written on my phone.)

EVaW-GGDEbYrYhgGUmO0DQ.review_text: I like the look of this place after the remodel. Our server was friendly and the food was really good. Before the remodel, I tried the food once and it wasn't bad. Better than Mel's Drive In.....not sure if that is saying much.   The food now is up to my standards.   AHI TUNA TARTARE served on Sticky Rice Cakes with Asian Pear, Wasabi, Sesame, Soy, Shiso Leaf-small bites size pieces. Really yummy. Love the crunch the rice cakes give with the tuna. Different from your typical won ton chips with tuna.   DEVILED EGGS with Crispy Quinoa, Bacon-this was so good. The crispy quinoa gave it that extra crunch. You have to really like mustard though, because they put Dijon mustard on the bottom of the egg, before they fill it with the yolk filling.   BRUSSELS SPROUTS  with Asian Pears, Ponzu-very well-seasoned. The pears add a nice touch to this dish.   CAULIFLOWER NUGGETS with Vadouvan Curry, Serrano Chile, Lime-this wasn't bad, but too much curry flavor for my liking.   FLAME GRILLED GARLIC SHRIMP with Tomato-Rosemary Pan Sauce, Garlic Chips-you get 4 pieces. Cooked perfectly and great flavor. Each shrimp was a decent size. It had a bunch of spinach on the bottom of the dish. Love!  WOOD OVEN CLAMS with Green Garlic Tomato Broth, Grilled Portobello Mushrooms, Straus Butter-pretty big size. Super yummy. Make sure you add the HAND-CUT FURIKAKE FRIES with Bonito Flakes, Garlic Aioli-it was crispy and thy give alot. Super yummy!

zFCw8uszWpKY7qRlrI0KAw.review_text: March 25 had an exceptional serving of steam clams at the bar.  April 10 ordered octopus salad at it was so unsatisfactory.  There was no presentation to the dish it looked as if it was a rush-defrost and throw on some dressing and serve. Thought I should post a WARNING!

S9U7bJYrUGLspHYsnyHeQw.review_text: I've always enjoyed going to Fog City Diner.  The remodel is nice, although for those who knew the "old" Fog City, it's not an easy adjustment.  The roast chicken, their signature dish, was great.  Good portion of food for two.  I had the roasted brussel sprouts and an awesome salad. Great meal.  It was very loud, so, be ready, but wasn't a big issue.

FHe8iR0zF5zt3NSiFyAk7w.review_text: It's really 3.5 stars. Fog City surprised me! I had not been to the diner before so there's nothing for me to compare it to.  The decor is nice and the service was great.   We ordered the cauliflower nugget which was delicious and very addicting. The kale & farro salad was just ok.. It was kinda bland.  We heard Fog City's chicken was comparable to the roasted chicken salad at zuni's so we had to try it. It was good. The chicken was juicy and very flavorful. The dish came with cabbage, onions and potatoes. I can't really compare it to zuni's because it's different. but it was definitely tasty. Although we were stuffed, we couldn't pass up on desserts when we saw the menu - frozen custard, homemade donuts.... HmMmmmMmmm yum.

-PoCbyNa4xc4yvReuj5pqw.review_text: I really want to like this place more. I feel very nostalgic towards it. But I just didn't have a great time. It's probably the fault of the obnoxious 60something year old man next to us on a Match.com first date, keep an eye out for his review I bet it's a doozy.  He ordered about 40 deviled eggs because as he proudly told his horrified date, he knew from his many former experiences here that one order wouldn't be enough. I'll return to this winner momentarily... My dinner was fine to middling, nothing to rave on Yelp about. Crab cakes (fine), fries (big pool of oil in bottom of bowl), broccoli (way too much lemon) and lamb skewers (served with butter lettuce cups to make some kind of wrap). Nothing outstanding there and some dishes verging on the edge of not edible due to tasting yucky. HOWEVER, my "I'm on a boat" cocktail was very very palatable so well done thank you very much. The doughnut is FANTASTIC. Get it with frozen vanilla custard and don't touch that disgusting orange sludge sauce on the side. Anyhow back to the awful man next to me on his date.  He told a not funny story in his bizarre fake deep radio announcer voice. I think it was about all the eggs not sitting well with him last time and then when his date suggested oysters (i think they were a tad pricey like almost deviled egg at urchin bistrot expensive) so he tried to sell her on the idea of them gettin ONE oyster each. When she said she was thinking a dozen he warned her multiple times he expected her to eat them all. I don't know how their date ended because we left but I do know that if I ever see this man again I will make sure to keep my distance, he loves eggs but they don't love him.

Te18TxvzfLomGE56N7s3Dw.review_text: I loved the old Fog City Diner.  It was one of my favorite places to eat partly because it was a diner, it felt like a staple of San Francisco and my mom and I would eat there after working out at the tennis club.  I was sad to see the place close down but was very excited to see that it reopened with the same name.  I had even higher hopes when I found out the group behind Bix and Zero Zero, two restaurants I particularly like were behind the reopening of this once great restaurant.  The restaurant kept the same facade, with windows wrapping around the restaurant however the inside is where they truly did a great job.  They made the restaurant completely open with a very comfortable, beautiful feel yet kept the booths which really gives you the old diner feel.  I really felt they did an exceptional job with that.  There is a bar right in the middle of the restaurant and an open kitchen that looks like something out of William and Sonoma.    We ordered a variety of things because it was plates to share and so we had the deviled eggs, furikake fries, clams, beef tongue and lamb.  The devil eggs were delicious; I usually don't like it and don't like eggs but they did a splendid job.  The furikake fries however weren't very good at all.  Too much oil in the fries and the fries were over fried along with not enough furikake and the mayo that came with it wasn't very good.  The furikake fries I had in Maui which had plenty of seasoning plus a great wasabi mayo was much better.  The clams didn't have any taste and the beef tongue had some vegetable in there that kind of ruined the dish.  I wasn't sure what it was but it wasn't very good.  The lamb was decent, came out in two long skewers and you ate like a lettuce wrap since they gave you lettuce, sauce and some condiments for it.  I really wanted the place to be much better but it wasn't as bad as my friend said it was (she said don't go, it's really not good).  I hope they improve the food because such a beautiful restaurant should have food to match its atmosphere.

QPRQcNaOb7Ooyx01zMlFjQ.review_text: Lunch food and service here are really good, but the noise level is off the charts.  Choose another place if you want to able to have a conversation.

4HUu0d1QsntSDK2nix4pqw.review_text: Overpriced tapas, waiter told us to order 7-10 plates at 15-30 a piece really? Burger was good everything else was over seasoned. Wait staff is attentive. Heard this place used to be great not impressed.

aLVxgd8GUNBnzmXZbVECMQ.review_text: Hadn't tried this place since they went through their "makeover" nor had any of my friends. I would definitely recommend it. We ordered mostly small plates and loved everything! The radicchio salad was possibly the best salad I've ever had. The service was excellent - I have a food allergy and the server alerted me to a problem I would never have suspected. And while this was date night, we both agreed we would come back to the bar, to watch a game, etc.

pJQNx6BsCyYGNNYlFdnfAQ.review_text: We came here for lunch a few times.  Wish they opened up a bit earlier.  We sat at the bar & the bartender was very nice.  We tried several drinks, all of which we enjoyed.  The food was great.  We started with the Furikake Fries.  I enjoyed them but my husband didn't like the shaved Furikake on it.  It was just too fishy for him.   I had the open faced turkey (Fog City Hot Brown) which was nothing of what I expected and very delicious.  My husband had the Saigon Dip and he devoured it all.  Overall, we liked it and will be back.

Pxky6wU2mkrht4YWE1YhLg.review_text: We ordered the following: ahi tuna tartar,  furikake fries, Brussels sprouts, garden salad, whole chicken, wild boar ribs, oven baked clams, and heritage pork chop. We were a party of five and we were definitely stuffed!  Here's a review of the food:  The fries, oven baked clams, Brussels sprouts, and whole chicken were very tasty. The chicken, in particular, was very moist and tender, absolutely delicious!  The wild boar meat was good. It fell right off the bones beautifully but the flavor was very one dimensional and under seasoned.  As I was eating it, I kept wishing for something to balance the umami fat flavor. The slaw that came with it was okay with it bc it was on the sour side. It tasted like tajin's flavor chili salt that Mexicans eat with fruits.   The heritage pork chop itself was the "worst" dish for me because it was on the dry side, and the sauce/bed of red cabbage and Fuji Apple did not enhance the flavors. The combo did not meld well.  It was a flop IMO.  It was also really small.  This restaurant loves their balsamic vinegar because the salad dressing was mostly that. I love balsamic vinegar dressings normally, but this one was just not done well. Pass.   Here's one of the reasons why I didn't give them a higher review. The ahi tuna came out with a piece of hair in the crispy rice at the bottom. It was stuck in there, I tried to pull it out thinking maybe someone's hair just dropped on it but it was deeply rooted in the rice. I should have taken a picture but i didn't want to make a big deal. Sometimes, accidents happen, it's okay with me.  However, it's how it was handled that really bugged me.  I pointed the hair to a waiter, who was rightly apologetic. He took the plate away and probably told the waitress and manager. The manager then hesitatingly came over and slowly approached us like we were going to chew his ears out. (Except, we were all calm and smiling because we were still enjoying ourselves despite the hair.) He kept a good table distance away from us too when he "apologized," it was as if we had cooties and he was afraid we'd give to it to him.  This is literally what he said, "I heard there was an unfortunate incident regarding one of your dishes. My apologies. I will remove it from your tab." That was while he was swiftly backing away. It was the most insincere and abrupt apology I've ever received from a business owner/manager ever! He said his piece and scurried off. I'd call that a record drive by apology of 5 seconds.  To add to the unsatisfactory service, they took one of our plates with that hairy tartar and did not replace it. I had to ask for it after more food kept coming out because I guess our waitress didn't realize we were missing a plate. Not her fault since she didn't take the plate away. But still, someone should have noticed.   When the bill came, the ahi tuna tartar was still on the bill.... The waitress realized it before we said anything so good for her because I would have said something.   I probably would come back just for the chicken. Everything else I can probably find at another restaurant with ease. The service was pretty good until the "unfortunate incident" happened. It was the manager's handling of the problem that really killed the experience for me. I'm sure your experience won't be as bad as long as you avoid hairy foods.

WjEmMLDWoKZMXes-h_Hg4A.review_text: The attitude here has been much more manageable at least during weekday lunch. Outside tables are nice.

CFtCdyGi319TOBaSG8x4qg.review_text: Simply bad...almost Denny's like bad.   Hostess was clueless as they have no sense of customer's intentions...empty place but she refused to give us a better table when we kind of stood there waiting...then the table had stains on it that seemed odd since this was relatively a new place.  The window area was cold and damp and my friend felt she caught a cold sitting there.  The noise from just a few tables in the area later was so bouncy that I could hear their conversation better than ours...very annoying and poor design.  The food missed big time.  The Brussel sprouts were charred beyond to a point of acridness.  The Deviled eggs seemed to ordered by every table was just blah...with weird crunchy elements on top.  The Minestrone soup was a complete disaster as it tastes of dishwater and served in a crooked cup.  The trout looked so amateurish like a culinary student put it together.  The steak had this awful topping and glaze that ruined what might gave been a decent cut.  The chicken which was suppose to be the star of the menu was dry and tasteless.  Worst was the mustard green leaves that were so old they looked like something from the bottom of your refrigerator.  The fingerlings were like boiled potatoes and the whole thing at $34 was a complete waste.  The four of us sat there eating the bread which they charge $3 for and had to add toppings at extra costs to frozen custard that appeared on three desserts.  The server was nice and kind of knew we didn't enjoy our meal...she deserves better.  This cannot be Bruce Hill food as even his worst night can't be this bad!

Z88N6qly3Dp5C06XbZ9IMQ.review_text: Bravo, Fog City.   It's a dingy diner no more! Your new self is sleek and contemporary; kudos on taking advantage of the smashing bay views. The brunch menu is short, but the choices are all standouts: belly busting chorizo hash, luscious crab benedict, fantastic maple glazed donuts!   I could go on, but what really cinched the deal are the uber fresh Marin Miyagi oysters. Have you ever had Oak Barrel aged hot sauce on these marvelous mollusks? pretentious? don't judge! well, if you do, then MORE for me!  A 3 hour brunch wouldn't be complete without tasty tipples. Go with any of the creatively named drinks like the Daredevil, Bad Moon Rising, an Inside Job or Grandpa's Breakfast. You won't be disappointed!  Sounds perfect? how about sidewalk seating while getting your tan on? ;-)  I'll stop here. I don't think you need anymore convincing.

dlp9xS7vCW23-p4ogwakUA.review_text: Do not! I repeat, DO NOT eat at this place!! Next time you decide to have lunch in SF, PLEASE avoid this place!! Not only are they ridiculously overpriced, but the only place close to me, but the burger had so much of whatever the hell the sauce was that I pacifically said I didn't want on! But the whole damn thing was just soggy as hell!! And top it off, I should have looked and that's my bad, the water I ordered wasn't even in the bag!! Again, just wanted to give you all a heads up! Ughhh!

eIa4QJXp5ZNmuFORnuPvDA.review_text: I had a really nice dinner here with a group of Yelpers to learn food photography. Needless to say there were a lot of cameras & selective questioning of the menu. The staff were really friendly about it. I really like the knife: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… SERVICE: We had a very fun, knowledgeable server. My table adored her, though I thought she was a little overbearing. She was very conscious of the order in which food came out, some of us being vegetarian, etc. COST: Total $38 or $46 a person (more if they got a drink) for 2 snacks, 7 plates, & 2 desserts, shared. MUST-HAVES: Cauliflower, brussels sprouts, crudo, shelling beans! Dinner menu: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… ~~SNACKS ($6)~~ * Cauliflower nuggets - 4.5 stars (vadouvan curry, serrano chile, lime) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… One of the faves. Amazing flavors - they sous-vide it & the flash deep-fry it. I thought the lime was a bit intense, but otherwise I loved the light, crisp breading. * Brussels sprouts - 5 stars (asian pears ponzu) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… This was one of my personal faves of the night. Great crisp, & asian pears - such a surprisingly great pairing! ~~PLATES TO SHARE~~ * Grilled mission fig salad - 4 stars (baby lettuces, point reyes blue, prosciutto, walnut gremolata. $14) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… I really liked the combo of flavors. If the walnuts were candied/toasted, that would've been the cherry on top. The blue cheese was sharp, I loved the salinity of the prosciutto, & the figs were very soft/sweet. * Spicy fire seared pole beans - 3.5 stars (cherry tomatoes, thai bird chilies, mint basil, garum & toasted sesame seeds. $10) The table loved this. It had an intense spicy taste, but there was a lemon flavor that was a little much for me, & I found the texture of the beans soggy/overcooked, not crisp as I like it. * Wood grilled tomato soup - 3.5 stars (stracciatella, basil, olive oil. $6) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… This was very simple & small. It did have a thick texture & was very fresh, smoky. * Oven roasted shelling beans - 4 stars (w/ smoky tomato butter & marjoram, garlic breadcrumbs. $13) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… A great heavy dish w/ lots of beans & a variety of textures. It also had hints of southern flavors. * King oyster mushrooms - 3 stars (red heart pimento-paprika stew, dill scented greek yogurt. $16) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… No one really liked this: two large mushrooms sitting in a tomato-like stew that was watery. Nothing too impressive, kind of bland. * Kampachi crudo - 4.5 stars (pickled asian pear, ginger, jalapeno cucumbers, & lemon olive oil. $16) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… I thought the ingredients were super fresh, & everything had an intense crunch. Each individual bite-sized portion came together perfectly. * Wood oven whole chicken - 4 stars (charred brentwood corn, crispy potatoes, & spiced maldon salt. $29) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… The chicken was a big overhyped. It was juicy & tender, but could've used more texture (some crisp on the skin) or more surprising flavors. The CORN - omg, that's where the dish was a real star! It was citrus-y, intense, juicy. Loved it! ~~SWEETS~~ Menu: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… * Green chili apple pie - 4 stars (hatch chiles, pippin apples, crispy topping, frozen custard. $7) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… I thought the peppers weren't strong but the others at my table really liked it. The textures were great w/ the thin buttery outer crust, sweet apples, & crumbles on top. * Panna cotta pudding cake - 3.5 stars (dark chocolate, milk chocolate, caramel candied peanuts. $8) pic: yelp.com/biz_photos/fog-… This had a little bit less of the milky flavor I like at panna cotta & was more jello-like, jiggly. The cake at the bottom layer was super light & fluffy, which I didn't think went well with the panna cotta layers. My table really liked this though.

phPiUMoU4JsA80hyw4iQmA.review_text: I came here without any expectations and was thoroughly surprised how nice our dinner turned out. It is a great local spot if you're in the mood to just wind down for a casual dinner.  I would go back for: Brussel Sprouts, Grilled Asparagus, Broccoli Di Cicco, Grilled Spanish Octopus Salad, and Wood Oven Whole Chicken.  I obsess over dessert as much as I do over dinner. Skip dessert.

_uRU_ktdOi_bjSOA-tcq2Q.review_text: Really love this place. Sorry to say, it was MUCH BETTER BEFORE! The new rehabbed place is still good, still a great place & I go as often as I can. Boo Hoo I miss the old one!

gi3VkcISbUpd0BQ68FerAQ.review_text: For the price point, very, very happy.  I liked the old Fog City, but didn't think it was much to write home for, the new one DEFINITELY is worth writing home.    The roast chicken is hands down the best I've ever had.  I have a soft spot for milk punch as its a family New Year's tradition.  Fog City's version is wonderful and unlike any other I've had.  When the waiter set it down I thought it was a vesper martini; his response when I asked "is this the milk punch" was "of course, we use clarified milk."  I had never heard of this but it works, and now I want to try and reverse engineer it!    In the near future I plan to try brunch.  My rating above is based on the 3 dinners I have had there since reopening.  Roast chicken steals the show for me, but the ribeye was also delicious and perfectly cooked.  Deviled eggs are great, French cruller is definitely worth the calories in all of its eggy citrusy goodness.

4ynWqCgExk56zfgmRmYRqA.review_text: This is a five ! I eat around the world and this is better than most, they have good service and good food when they are slammed. Prices are high , but worth it if you actually care about food.  Not for cheap, winey , or annoying  people . Did you wonder just now if you are one of those people , then you are .  Spend $100 and enjoy yourself.

jAiGoRmj3eAkeH_3KfudXg.review_text: We popped into Fog City after an afternoon at the Exploratorium. I'm not sure what the place looked like pre-remodel in its diner days, but I love the new decor. Sleek, simple, with clean lines, good natural light and lots of wood.  We sat at the bar ordering drinks and a snack. He went with a beer and I a play on a margarita with a chile.* Our bartender was a doll; I'm not really one for small talk, but we chatted with her easily while we were there. To eat, we ordered the Early Morning Tomatoes. The description was a little deceptive, we thought we'd be getting a flatbread, but it was more like a tomato salad with flatbread croutons. We loved the dish but agreed that more chevre would have improved it.  If the rest of Fog City's food is like the drinks and appetizer we had, it's worth a stop. I'd definitely make a stop in again if I was on the Embarcadero.  * The chile that comes with this drink may be small, but the manfriend ate it and it is hot. Have something to blunt the heat at the ready, it is h-o-t, hot.

OI-h0R6CoJtR5LK6zLrvww.review_text: Amazing service and food. Great open kitchen and unique flavors. Try the Saigon dip. It is a zesty treat.

TCWDxGDYUC0NkUrq_Ka7pg.review_text: Doesn't look like much on the outside, but the interior is well designed yet maintains a casual, relaxed atmosphere.  They had great drink / brunch specials.  I enjoyed a few bloody mary's while my friend had the milk punch.  He said it was good but it was rather small.  The saigon dip is delicious and a must try.  The wood oven brown is also a hot plate of delicious that just makes you want to curl up on the couch and relax.  The service is good and the staff is friendly.  The bill was rather pricey for a brunch.

TLzwLBhPoO33w85VOXz97g.review_text: There was an ugly old frustrated unhappy waiter here ruined our dinner. 7 of us were having a family dinner went so bad, annoyed us. The waiter, about 65, full gray hair, 5'8" high, 230lb stocky, big nose, dominator idiot, giving us a lecture of the menu, telling us what he likes or not. His mouth smelled so bad like rotten Tofu like, or I must say, 17 days old mackerel.  He was very rude to us. Such a self centered character that he thinks he is better than anybody, the kind. Who the hell cares for your opinion?  Just get me a food, Bitch!  Well, also, the most of food was underwhelming. We had the crab cakes, which were tasty but small. OK, they were on the menu as a 'small plate', but at $16 they were very disappointing.  My friend had the chicken salad which was $17--extortionate, considering it was brown chicken meat and lettuce with a minimal amount of all the other ingredients (Tory Farm Nectarines, Marinated Cabbage, Candied Peanuts). Personally, I find it BAFFLING how restaurants can charge such high prices for what is, essentially, 10 cents worth of lettuce and less chicken than you get in a single chicken tender from KFC. Ridiculous.  You pay $15 for a shitty burger that doesn't even come with fries. The bun was soggy. The lettuce was sparse. The meat didn't really taste like anything and was a thin patty. Man. I got through about 3 bites and called it quits.  Overall, 'meh' is a great word to describe Fog City. It's a shame, because it could be more upbeat, be much better value for money and have more personality/individuality. But being where it is (right near the Pier buildings and near a constant stream of tourist traffic) the owners probably don't think they need to bother making any extra effort.  I don't like the dominator waiter. I feel really sorry for him. What a Frustrated Ugly Old Fart!  Cherylynn N. For my review of: Fog City "Well, I guess I know what to skip!"  Yes, you should Skip Fog City!

TqJmcgvFJXUv3joEK8p-yg.review_text: What a great time on Saturday. First of all,service was 5 stars'!!! The hostess,our server,the manager all rocked   Our meal was awesome. !!the kale salad,shrimp and grits, incredible burger and the custard all were delicious   Will definitely be back! Highly recommend

KzroPmvVkyshPwRDgLBwEw.review_text: I had a bad experience with the crowd in this restaurant.I raised the issue with the manager. One other thing - They charge for the bread which they serve with the entrees.

BgWaJDXga_iqOqxIYaxrrw.review_text: Fog City I want to love you but...I've tried you 4 times and... Service: lacking and often rude servers. If you sit outside you have a good chance of being forgotten.  Food: Mediocre and way overpriced.  Parking: hit or miss. Can be a nightmare. Will ticket on Sundays  Chorizo Hash: $17 French toast $14 It's like eating room service food and paying for it.

L5INIE0xCZdFKZMcpyWLQw.review_text: Creative, non-pretentious and absolutely delicious.   The Woodfired cooking shines through in every dish, from appetizers to desserts.   Go with a group and share the plates. Chef Bruce Hill and his team have a passion for offering creative, sustainable and delicious food.

HYeP6_BNSQYSB_oR-SqiLA.review_text: Missed the old decor.  Thought the brunch menu limited.  Expected lunch menu but  it wasn't available on a Saturday.  Hamburger overpriced for size, quality.  Thin, cooked medium, not rare.  Fries good without the fishy addition.

BIkivGwMblK3_r2N0pSE8A.review_text: My family had lunch here on a beautiful summer afternoon.  I have not been here since the remodel, the space is now beautiful and modern while retaining just a bit of the old diner.  My wife and son ordered cheeseburgers and they seemed to be happy with them.  I ordered the Saigon Dip and found it to be unique and delicious.  A cross between a French Dip and Banh Mi served with delicious Pho broth for dipping rather than Au Jus.  For dessert we shared an order of the chocolate crullers.  There was too much chocolate for me, I would have preferred a dusting of cinnamon & sugar.  We'll likely come here again if we are in the neighborhood...

Rx7DNBmPPShVjlcQidGuTw.review_text: i came here on sunday w/ 5 friends and we shared a bunch of stuff.  the brussels sprouts, cauliflower fritters and deviled eggs were all great.  i also think the broccoli di ciccio and roasted carrots were yummy.  i shared the trout as well, and it was light and perfectly cooked.   the desserts were ok tho (apple pie, small bites and the pot de creme).  i probably could have done w/o them.

jgtHDLB5JSmwV5PX5ml_Tw.review_text: every thing is better than it was.

BsV1OSz6IYPzV-ekTqJIoA.user_location: Playa Del Rey, Los Angeles, CA
BsV1OSz6IYPzV-ekTqJIoA.review_text: Great food and service. The addition of the wood burning grills is fantastic. We had the grilled fig salad, grilled pole beans, beef tongue salad and the Swordfish. All were prepared perfectly. Figs were carmelized well, the pole beans had just enough spicy heat, the tongue was very tender and the swordfish simply grilled to let its own flavor standout. My only disappointment was the fact that we were fighting off fruit flies from our plates and drinks through the whole meal. Other than that it was a great experience.

OsHLf1WYFti775iMNgwSUg.review_text: A local pointed us here - we were trying to get out of tourist hell down by the piers and a lovely gentleman walking his dog suggested it. So happy to find it! Service was superb, informed, fast, genuinely friendly and accommodating. The space itself is absolutely beautiful and unique. Cozy yet sleek.  Shared the paprika and bacon peanuts (addicting). I had the onion soup and kale salad, and husband had the burger - everything was fresh, well prepared and high quality. We also shared the delicious garlicky fries. I wish this place was closer to home, we'd go all the time! A highlight of this trip!

uqOizjedeV43lEiwJa5RNQ.review_text: Under rated.  Lamb kebabs, burger, brussels, fries, kale salad...the dishes were not unique, but they were much tastier than any other spot serving the same concept.  My drinks were better than any other $12 cocktails I've had in awhile.   Loved that they added heaps of bar seating in the makeover.  Perhaps happiness came from sitting at the bar with simple expectations as opposed to formal table service.

KMKtLIaFzkJA3yHqqlG-Bw.review_text: This was the worst dining experience of my life. Our party of four was verbally harassed by a completely intoxicated patron and management's response only added insult to injury. Not to mention that the food was sub par, at best. To be fair, we left before the entree (because the verbal abuse continued) so I can only speak for the several appetizers we tried but they did not impress. We were looking forward to having a celebratory dinner and seeing how the renovations have improved the restaurant but unfortunately, it was a total disappointment and a complete waste of money. We basically paid 200$ for some lousy appetizers, drinks, and to be treated horrifically. I at least expected the staff to be helpful and take action but they did just the opposite.  I will never return nor will I recommend this restaurant to anyone.

jhec3G37jetpori8IFnGAw.review_text: The food was good.  However, our dinning experience was adversely impacted by the long delay of food and reversed order of main course and much delayed soup due to computer entry error per the manager.  The manager was apologetic and did not charge us the soup at the end.  Unfortunately, my evening was not as fun as I had expected.

GIupQf3nYTPuHkMfEUEm5Q.review_text: One Star is for the renovations they did to the restaurant - it looks great now!  Nice seating and gorgeous bar!  Wood fire oven and overall a great layout!  Second Star is for the service.  While it wasn't "amazing" or anything, it was quite nice.  Everyone was very polite, came in a timely manner, and our water was refilled frequently!   As a server myself, I appreciate good service, and I definitely had it here.  Minus Three Stars for the food.  Honestly, it was not only not "good" but I think very very bland and tasteless.  I almost never say that about food!  Even the friend I was with had the EXACT same thing to say.  We had the Lamb (which wasn't too bad), the fries ("eh") and the Fog City Burger.  The burger had NO TASTE WHATSOEVER!  I couldn't believe it.... Then we traded it out for a Grilled Shrimp Entree, which was hard/rubbery and way over-salted.  Completely lost our taste for dessert and quite frankly, we just wanted to jet outta there!  It was nice they took the two items we didn't like off our bill, as would be expected, but I really wanted to pay for them and like them!  Ugh... wasn't very pleasant in that sense, but like I said, good service and decor, but really the point is to eat and with that it wasn't good.  The bread and Fog City Mule (drink) were great though!

ES8LX7rVlq3i5RCB30Tv2w.review_text: Used to enjoy this place back in it's "Fog City Diner" days, so decided to celebrate Hubby's 56th bday there.  Definitely NOT a diner anymore.  It never really was, but all that's gone now except some of the booths.  The food is upscale, beautiful, well-presented and amazing.  Service good, but perhaps a few more servers would suit the crowd better. I really appreciated the absolutely delicious fruit bowl I was able to request for dessert in deference to sugar issues.  Some of the best fruit I've ever had and they were kind enough to put a candle in Hubby's frozen custard. His Ribeye was a thing of well-marbled cholesterol-ridden beauty.  My big problem is the noise. Without the booths separating the patrons it's absolutely  impossible to have even a modicum of privacy or avoid the conversations of your neighbors. Not that I minded hearing about the new dog, but the marriage problems from the other side were a decided non-enhancement to the otherwise delicious meal.

ZTptQ-2dpmHjSt43g0JnzQ.review_text: I went on a Sunday to try out the newest version of this restaurant. I really love the neighborhood, so I was really hoping for the best. Unfortunately their website has the wrong hours, so when I went there Sunday afternoon, I was told I had to wait two hours to get an actual meal. I pointed out the problem with the website (showing it to the manager with my phone) and I was assured they would get it fixed on Monday. That was a month ago and still no changes. I was told by the hostess that several people had come in with the same problem, wrong hours. Since I'd traveled a hour to get there, I decided to have a couple of snacks at the bar and try to fool myself into thinking it was a meal. The fries were really unremarkable and the second dish I don't even remember, though I do remember being underwhelmed. Definitely left with a bad taste in my mouth.  So take this as less of a message about if a regular meal would be good, and more of a warning to people going during weekends, the kitchen is closed in the afternoons. Also to the staff of the restaurant, PLEASE put the correct hours on your website.

6NpP6p_h8ueGRbtQ2qBd-w.review_text: My friends had been telling me to come here since the remodel, etc.  I finally made it.  I never came here in its previous life, as I am not a 'diner' person.  No problem now - it doesn't feel like a diner at all; it feels like a comfortable, classy restaurant you can have a good business lunch at.  I loved the choice of materials on the interior, particularly in the bathrooms with the mix of tiles and woods.  We all ordered the 'chicken noodle' soup and it was hands down the best soup I have ever had in my life.  Nearly one of the best meals I have had.  And I don't like chicken.  The house made noodles, seared brussel sprouts, kale, and excellent broth were a winning combination served in my favorite Heath bowls.  My one complaint would be that it was actually too much food.  Classy, professional, unobtrusive service.  I will definitely be back again.

WcnnhT_FxKGop-W2mYnprQ.review_text: Love this place!! The new look is exactly what this place needed while keeping some of the charm. Brunch is fun and the food is good.

lNFD3AhH-vqh893vbUpO0g.review_text: The burger, a staple of any restaurant, left much to be desired.  The vegetable dishes and apps were OK.  The cheese crisps ended up being overpriced Chez-Its.  The only thing that saved Fog City from the being completely consumed by the storm were the service, atmosphere, and the cocktails.

ZSqMkleQk2l1_KRhSlYnfA.review_text: I have been here twice now, once with friends and once when I was a alone while my BF was away for a weekend.  I experienced booth service and bar service; the restaurant was busy both nights I was there.  I had a great service experience with my first server Diana ( i had to ask her name because I loved her so much)   I have to admit that both times I had the cheeseburger and fries.  Both are delicious.  I often complain about potato preparation here in California because I am from potato country- ND.  The burger is like a really amazing fast food style burger- thin patty, the perfect toppings and a soft bun.  Only cooked medium-rare, but it doesn't matter.  I you love thick burger's this is not for you.   Personally, I like the renovation, it is definitely different and I like seeing the whole restaurant while dining. I had eaten at the old Fog City and did enjoy the food but had a bad service experience, so for me this is much better. Thanks for making a burger and fries that I love! And the drink menu is tasty too.

snI32nf_QziTT1Tk9DgapA.review_text: Amazing! can't believe I've lived here for 6 years and had never tried this place. Great food, great wine list, and amazing staff and service. Kampachi crudo was amazing and their cocktails are delightful. Don't skip this place!

XX5G1gpBLzv-oXJGlRvfoQ.review_text: Amazing. I've been raving to anyone that will hear me out about this restaurant since I was here recently.   I've never been to the diner that was before the restaurant was remodeled, but I'm super glad it was revamped!  The food here is all family style, though some of the dishes might come out smaller than the others and some are a little more massive.  There was 6 of us for the evening and here's what we ordered:    Snacks:  - Hand-cut Furikake Fries Garlic Aioli - Brussels Sprouts Asian Pears Ponzu (This does come with fish flakes, those ones you find on takoyaki, so veggies beware)  Veggies: - King Oyster Mushrooms  Seafood:  - Kampachi Crudo (this was definitely on the smaller side) - Wood Oven Clams  Meats:  - Wood Oven Whole Chicken (we got 2 of these) - Berkshire Pork Cheeks  Everything was pretty delicious.  Highlights were definitely the meats.  The Pork Cheeks were super soft and just melts in your mouth delicious.  And the Whole Chicken!!! I couldn't rave more about them.  Its boneless and so juicy and tender, it puts any and all other roasted chicken you've had to SHAME!  If there's only 1 thing you would order here, FOR GODS SAKE ORDER THE CHICKEN!!! It is so good.  This place also has an amazing bar with a great range of whiskeys and cocktails.  But most importantly mocktails for the littlies or designated driver.   This place is also kid friendly and is large enough to easily accommodate for large groups.  Though make sure you book ahead.  This place gets very busy and would be hard to get seats without a booking.   Oh yeah and order the chicken!

dl8Zxx9BKUFErcA5usaoHw.review_text: I went here for lunch and I didn't realize you needed a reservation. Regardless, we sat what they call a community table. It's basically one long table (like at the bar). I was okay with that. I ordered the burger. It was juicy and yummy and the bun was not soggy at all. My husband ordered the smoked salmon smorrebrod.  He really enjoyed it. We didn't care for the hand cut furikake fries. They were just all right. When we first placed our ordered, we ordered 4 dishes (burger, salmon, fries and their brussels sprouts).I was a bit disappointed that all our food came and by the time my burger, my brussel sprouts finally came. Keep in mind, there was a family a table over that orderd after us and they received their brussel sprouts before me. That was a bit let down for me. Will I go again? Probably not. It was okay. I can say I finally went after their remodel.

U4INQZOPSUaj8hMjLlZ3KA.review_text: Items Selected: Warm Old Fashioned Doughnuts - Sugar Dusted Aaron's Buttermilk Biscuits - Strawberry Compote Fog City Hot Brown - Roasted Heritage Turkey, Country Sourdough, Mornay Sauce, Nueskie's Bacon, Roma Tomato Brioche French Toast - Yerena Farm Strawberries, Maple Whipped Cream, Shaved Almonds  With the meeting adjourned for lunch and several hours of digestion aided by Moscone Center coffee now behind me it was up the Embarcadero that I again marched and this time traveling farther north than usual it was just past one o'clock when I sat down at Fog City, a gregarious middle-aged gentleman with a sweaty brow providing Michelin-quality service to myself as well as patrons both inside and out during a nearly 75-minute brunch.  Seemingly understaffed at the front-of-the-house while a team of five manned the open fire oven and stoves in the kitchen it was with one famous dish on my mind that I entered Fog City but featuring a recently renovated brunch menu promising several personal favorites my order instead unfolded in three parts, an opening duo of cinnamon-sugar brioche donuts a touch too bready while flaky golden biscuits varnished in sugar and butter proved exemplary.  Moving onward to the original object of my desire it was after a nearly thirty minute delay that Fog City's riff on the Louisville Hot Brown arrived and gussied up with artisan touches as only The Bay Area can do suffice it to say that it puts J. Graham's original to shame - a bubbling pot of creamy Mornay smothering tangy sourdough and smoked turkey with a crown of crisp bacon and lightly griddled tomatoes added straight from the pan.  Clearly unwilling to pass on dessert it was with a small menu of frozen custards, crullers, and shortcake that I was presented and although the later featured the strawberry finale I desired so did the brunch menu French Toast, a buttery trio of triangles so saturated with maple-infused custard that the interior was nearly liquid beneath a crunchy golden coat ready to be dressed in even more maple, whipped cream, and lightly reduced berries that made me wonder not only why more has not been said of this dish but why anyone would sell themselves short with the shortcake.

CjEIOODtdG2yloVWGmraOg.review_text: Well...  I came here over 20 years ago and while I don't remember anything about the place, when I came across it a few years back, I had an awesome time. A perfect hamburger unique to how I ever had it and a bonus of a Stoli O with 7. Yum. So of course the next time I came to SF I was so looking forward to recreate. And then the big disappointment that it had closed down. Today by chance I drove by and to my delight, they're back!!  I couldn't wait for my perfect cheeseburger. DONT BE FOOLED BY THE NAME DINER.  This is by no means a diner. I say they revamped into a swanky hip chic loud restaurant. Really not a place my kids would like. In fact I found it hard to find anything other than a hamburger that I would order. I wasn't ready for duck at a "diner".   Well here's the sad fact. The burger, well, umm..I didn't enjoy it at all. I've had better at 5 guys or even sonic. Nothing special. I feel bad that a place I once revered is now nothing but a memory. Perhaps if I have a different mindset going in and want to not have a conversation with my company, I'll try it again. Just maybe but not likely. ,

7Aoc10uCOU9utZ0HV6gABA.review_text: The wood oven chicken is mouth-wateringly delicious!  I would go back just for the chicken.  It arrives on a cast iron skillet, and the waiter very nicely cut it for us.  The meat was so tender, I think he just used a butter knife!  The skin on the outside was crisp and perfectly seasoned, and even the white meat was incredibly juicy and tender.  The dark meat was sooo rich, it came close to achieving the umami flavor usually only obtainable by red meat!  I also think Fog City in general is a pretty good deal for the portion size.  The whole roast chicken is only $34 compared to Zuni's $48.  The butter lettuce salad served 2 generously and could have served 3 or 4 adequately for around $10.  $7 for "snacks," like the rich, slightly tangy deviled eggs or brussels sprouts seems totally fair to me since most are healthy sized and require thought and consistent preparation.  Finally, get the milk punch.  It's smooth, beautiful, spicy, and fascinatingly creamy in taste while crystal clear.

kUSYOi3eLzOfxhlwbE2UFg.review_text: Went to the newly reopened, but completely changed, now named Fog City but use to be Fog City Diner.  Have to say, I'm not impressed.  I was really excited to try Fog City but walked away wanting more.  Pro's - Remodel looks great!  Great décor, nice feel. - Wine list looks good, came for lunch so couldn't partake since I had to go back to work :(  Con's - Food-  there was nothing on the menu that I was super excited to try.  I have to say I wish they would have left a few of "Fog City Diners" best on the menu, like the mac n cheese, mmm.  Plus what we did order didn't wow any of us.  From the Saigon sandwhich to the filet of sole (with burnt brussel sprouts), we all left thinking eh it wasn't bad it just wasn't particularly good either. - Service was SLOW, I get it their busy but service was definitely lacking.  We had to remind our server several times for our drinks, condiments, etc.  Overall I think I would return for cocktails at the bar, maybe with an order of their fancy French fries but not for another meal.

ve79_AjkbLemDoZHL7AiVA.review_text: We arrived early for our reservation, so we were able to enjoy incredibly-priced happy hour oysters!  The best I've ever had for just $1.50 a pop.  Also, a scrumptious Moscow Mule.  We ordered lots of I different plates.  The best were the short-rib tacos with kimchi, the beets with crème fraise, deviled eggs (works of art!), and the lamb satay.  The only disappointment were the orange-glazed crullers.  They were sort of burnt on the outside and doughy on the inside.  Worst donut I've had in my life.  Note to cook--your oil wasn't the right temperature.

ql-JNHMqpseFUbB6p-b-sg.review_text: Ahhhhhh Fog City...... Everything about you I should hate, but I don't! The wife and I had an amazing time! Great food, fresh new look, amazing cocktails! Whats not to like???

xcb2-yMQbrjkSnhrzdGssQ.review_text: $17. hamburger review . . .  You would expect a patty larger than 1/4 lb. and gee, you might even expect it to be cooked the way you asked for it.  When the waiter asked how it was I said that it was overcooked. He explained that it was a burger that was "a tribute" to fast food burgers.  No apology.  This burger was a tribute to a turd.  I don't know about the rest of the menu but I would steer clear of this item.

JO3vGw-PuagZMXOzl84BmQ.review_text: I really wanted to love the new and improved fog city, I used to eat there growing up in SF! It looks beautiful and the menu seemed interesting, if not overpriced and a bit unfocused. My mom, brother and i shared a salad and for our main my mom and I asked to split a burger and my brother ordered pork cheeks. The burger (14$ and not a lot of meat!!) came on a piece of wood with no sides and with 4 toothpicks in it. Strange to begin with...but then we sat there with our burger in front of us for 15 minutes being polite before my brothers entree came! We complained to our waiter since our burger was cold at that point and he said, "oh, you're meant to share". Hmm ok. So you want me to slice a burger into thirds at the table and share it?! Weird. The manager gave us the same response too!! Since when is the customer wrong?? In the end the food was pretty good, but the strange "share everything" (thats not prepared to be shared!) and the bad attitude of the staff will keep us from coming back :(

PxkCVu2T4_g--oFKAyOmig.review_text: I loved the newly designed diner!   My husband and I thoroughly enjoyed our meal and entire experience.  We will definitely be back next time we are in town.

NOXtQrk0YqOt5QlYN3X2Rg.review_text: I visited Fog City on Sunday, October 13th, for the first time since the renovation. I had been to the original Fog City Diner (or, as  Phil Frank put it, the "Fog City Dumpster" :-D unfortunately, those "Farley" comics which used to hang prominently on the wall near the bathrooms are no longer there) a few times and absolutely loved the ambiance and the food. Unfortunately, I cannot say the same for the revamped Fog City. I admit that this review is in part jaded by my instinctual comparisons between Fog City and the Fog City Diner, but perhaps it will still help someone.   First, the ambiance. I'm old-fashioned and loved the Art Deco look that the original Fog City Diner had. I knew that the interior had been remodeled, but even still, I was disappointed to find how radically different it was. I would use the word "trendy" to describe the interior now...the look may age well and it may not, but it felt like any other "modern upscale" restaurant that I've set foot into. Again, I really liked the charm of the old Diner, so your experience may be different, but I found the new look to be bland, unoriginal, and unimpressive. Also, while this may have been in part because the place was fairly busy, I got the impression from the gentleman at the front desk that, as a single diner, I was tolerated rather than welcomed. At the same time, the waiter treated me very well. It's also worth noting that the place was very noisy, with people packed very close to one another...as a single diner who generally likes to concentrate on a good book while eating, I didn't like this, but this could be a positive point for some.  Now, to the meat of the matter...the food. I'm about one of the most predictable people you'll ever meet; if it's available, I'm ordering a plain cheeseburger and fries (and, if it's not available, I'm usually not eating at that restaurant). After placing my order, the food came surprisingly quickly. The fries were good for the most part...nice and crispy, and the seasoning was okay, although there was something in the topping that almost tasted fishy; I can't really put my finger on what it was. The burger, however, was a bit of a disappointment. I wouldn't say that it was bad, but for the price, I expected something more. I think the kitchen changed their source of beef; I was impressed by the burger at the old Fog City Diner, and I'll admit that that expectation may be part of the source of my disappointment. But, the beef was all but tasteless, and seemed to be swimming in the cheese.  Finally, I should say something about the price. The menu listed the burger at $14, which isn't unreasonable. However, I was surprised when I received the check and found that the fries were a separate menu entry, for $6! I had assumed that the fries came with the burger; that's my fault for not double-checking...but, what used to cost maybe $18 is now pushing $30, for what most would consider a fairly basic meal. Note that that price doesn't include a drink; I generally only drink water (teetotaler and I don't like soda). Given that, and that my food orders are generally less expensive than that of others, I think rating this restaurant a "3" on the Price Range is more than fair.  In conclusion, while the waiter did a great job, I was underwhelmed by the front desk, and while the food was not awful, I don't think it was a good value at that price. So, especially considering how many options there are in the immediate area, I regret to say that I don't think I'll be returning to the place that used to be my favorite spot to eat in San Francisco. I imagine that there are many who love the revamp, but I'd really like to see the return of the original Fog City Diner!

vH4ac_IkrPtVyBP-i0GTBw.review_text: Interesting decor; definitely a different feel from fog city diner (less warm, more sophisticated).  Service was solid, and the bartender was very accommodating of our requests to taste several of the wines on tap before making a selection.  Food was actually quite good, although on the pricey side.  I would recommend the fries and deviled eggs.  The fig salad and trout were both tasty, but I've had much better versions of both for considerably less.

Z-4Ow2j7kRPyUMuxsebmvQ.review_text: Disagree with 3.5 stars. Been here twice.  Both times very good. The second time was more like 4.5 stars. Among other excellent dishes, we had the wood oven roasted chicken, prepared in an iron skillet. I'd say this was one of the best dishes in the city. Hope they keep that one on the menu. Loved the atmosphere, location, service. Good stuff all around.

OZE_X5_bUbEmFpiewqfi2Q.review_text: missing landmark..    wanted to love the re-design so very much.  I tried.  must admit food is pretty good, and I'm sure they genuinely believed this iconic diner could be improved.  but it sadly lost it's soul.  prices went up, bathrooms got fancy,  history erased.  I'll cherish my memories of hungover brunch with my sweetheart, and washing it down with the best (no longer avail) chocolate malt money could buy.  RIP fog city DINER.

DhIw6ihlO7u_wvKMMNqvTw.review_text: good food and view yet with limited options

5movf4njIHTuBOl9zNX7Iw.review_text: Disappointing, after the charm of the old fancy diner.  I'm sure they're getting a lot more business now, but I suspect this will deteriorate before long.  Seemed like they tried to create something derivative of nearby Piperade or Park Tavern, but without good food, professional service, or unique ambiance.  If they fix the menu it could take a step up... lots of great concepts and ingredients, combined in the pathetic ways.  For example, the beef tongue meat itself was lovely, but being doused in bacon and balsamic, it was ruined.  Needs some class.

Fg7AGfgmEnBrbIglch9eaw.review_text: I hadn't been to Fog City in 25 years, then  heard recently that it had been remodeled.  Last night was surprisingly balmy so it occured to me it might be fun to meet a friend there to check it out.  Because of the weather, we took an outside table with the intention of going in to check out the new decor before we left.   The waitress and hostess were efficient and nice and we ordered the brussels sprouts, beets, deviled eggs and butter lettuce salad to split.  It was delivered by what appeared to be the manager - a 50ish guy who let me know with a well-practiced sneer that he wouldn't be bringing me the salt and pepper I requested.  Sure enough, he blew off my request for condiments and we got flavorless sprouts, beets, eggs and salad - needed some tabasco too - from an ungrateful "mgr" that will never again overcharge me (with wine, over $100) for mediocre food.  Tourists:  check out Tadich, Big Four, il Fornaio (around the corner) and/or any of about 100 (no kidding) tasty, fun and service-oriented restaurants within walking distance from this trap.

B56OgCiDdS7ilyl7afcJtw.review_text: I was a little worried about this place as when you get in they tell you that you probably want to share appetizers (sort of tapas).  I was with a large group and had already looked at the menu and knew I wanted the steak...(was sort of worried I would have to share that and I don't like sharing my dinner LOL).  We all started off with appetizers, cauliflower nuggets - AMAHHHZING... Quinoa deviled eggs - DELICIOUS... Grilled asparagus - eh.. It had UFOs (Unidentified Food Objects) on it so I wasn't a fan (and it didn't seem grilled) Cheddar bites - more like gourmet cheez its... But tasty.  Regular bread, nummy... So I did order my Rib Eye steak and to be honest, I don't usually like steak unless my hubby BBQ's it for me...  This steak was heaven, no joke delicious and cooked perfectly.  Argula and fingerling potatoes as sides, nom nom...  Hubby had the wild boar ribs and they were small but a big portion and super tasty!  People were asking left and right for tastes...  The chicken was super moist and oh so tasty...  I heard the pork chops weren't cooked good but when they came back they were better but just okay.  Beer and wine, great selection.  Dessert - nom nom nom...  At first I thought who is putting donuts on their dessert menu?  They were delicious as was the frozen custard with the strawberry topping.  If you are into Affogato or however it's spelled, you will like it here according to some tablemates...  Can't wait to go back and get another steak and cauliflower bites - Who wudda thunk I would enjoy a vegetable so much I would mention it more than once in a review?

mze2Sa7eFZbxU9zE2o-jBA.review_text: It's not that the food isn't good. It's not that I miss so terribly the Diner of Fog City. It's that it's been more than six months since my last incident, and I regret the discrimination experienced at a restaurant at which I used to LOVE to dine.   Imane served my husband and me a delicious meal of Eggs Benny. However, our enjoyment was tarnished by the apparent racism in the initial seating, and for that reason, we will not be returning. Although first in line when the restaurant opened this morning, we were walked to table #28, the one right in front of the register with a poor view, foot traffic, and inevitable endless conversation by the staff that gather there. The restaurant was not remotely full (and wasn't when we finally left), but when we asked to be reseated to a similar table two chairs away, the gentleman who seated us said, "I'll have to check. The host assigned this table specifically." As he walked away, a White couple who asked to be reseated out of the same section was immediately offered a booth, no one checking with the host first. We indeed received a new table (not a booth), and soon thereafter two Black women were relegated to the table we just vacated, suffering the same push back when asking to be reseated: "I'll have to check." They were offered the booth by the door, a slightly better but by no means top choice location.  I hope that in the future, not only will the worst tables in the restaurant be reserved for final seating when Fog City actually is full, but also that there is more sensitivity to patterns of behavior such that they might be self-regulated. Diversity or anti-bias training perhaps?  I used to enjoy Fog City Diner every other weekend when I lived in San Francisco and never experienced such indignity. I hope service can return to those days ... although I won't be returning to find out.

ruYZyeZmcXZXmaQZpUXQ3w.review_text: Boooooooooooo. Burger was nearly as good as In N Out but 4x the price. Cocktails were good though, so I'll stick to boozing next time

2KJeI4NWyfSbTXnEGc0qiw.review_text: We were surprised by the lack of comfort food options.  We used to love coming here before the renovation, the previous menu and service were classic.

fZP1xM8h3ev2zeVAYHN3cg.review_text: Great service. Really delicious smoked salmon + kale salad. Issues: they charged us for bread and they were out of hamburgers... What diner runs out of hamburgers at 2 pm? I do like this place though!

9QITXadhXwFd08ZO1sNnJg.review_text: I love the new Fog City.  The décor is beautiful and the food is great.  I highly recommend the Kampachi Crudo and the Berkshire Pork Cheeks.  The service was great except for the hostess, who was a bit surly.  We'll definitely be back soon!

iQhuapjBn0RlVc_1TAPZlg.review_text: Our waiter could care less if he attended to us. We seemed to be a bother to him. My flounder was a small piece of fish the size of my hand, the few brussel sprouts sprinkled were too charred that they flaked like a burnt piece of paper and I was told that's how they come.  My husband's hamburger was oversalted and neither meal was worth the price.  I don't mind spending money for quality but it just wasn't there.

dfNos8n_vBmUS34OFgPrbQ.review_text: Great food, great people, and great atmosphere.  I am particularly in love with the Burger.  I've gone to this multiple times just for drinks, just for dinner, and for both.  The food really fits the setting and I'll continue to go here when I can.

wpEs0WjOpHL0ZdUnSg3F0Q.review_text: What was once a favorite restaurant of my girlfriend and I has disappointed us. We use to make this our anniversary, birthdays and when in town restaurant. With the lack of charm that it use to have even beautiful inside feels kind of cold. The true disappointment of the night was the menu! Unfortunately nothing left of the original menu and lack luster of "entries" I don't think you can call $15 burger that looks like it came from Carl's Jr. a meal. Sadden by this what was a restaurant visited for more than 5+ years will not have our business again. Quick tip: If it's not broken don't fix it. Maybe it's a new owner and trying to follow in footsteps of other restaurants around but the sad part it's no longer original.

dcjrPcU-q7sxF0L_E1YqdA.review_text: Stumbled upon Fog City on our way to climb the stairs to Coit Tower (god help me).  Sat at the bar and ordered a Moscow Mule, which was very good.  Decent vibe and the menu looked good. Had we not just left Reds Java House (awesome burgers), we would have stayed for lunch. I obviously survived the stair climb to Coit Tower, if you were wondering.

m07sy7eLtOjVdZ8oN9JKag.review_text: Oh my, I can still remember when this place was called Mildred Pierce's way back when I was a poor assistant media planner in an ad agency near the Levi Plaza. I believe that was sometime after Pearl Harbor and before my last memory lapse. Then it became Battery Point for a minute and then changed identities again around the mid-80's to Fog City Diner. Believe it or not, it used to be a trendy place to go, although the retro-diner vibe became so commonplace and the menu so misbegotten with its festering Mexican and Asian small plate selections, that it finally sputtered into oblivion last year. I don't think I even made it over there in over a decade, and even in its new guise, I was hesitant to go until a food blogger raved about how good the food was. Fog City? Really? Chef/owner Bruce Hill has indeed dropped the Diner part of the moniker and now it's simply Fog City. The place looks much more sleek and contemporary with dark wood accents but still with the windows facing the splintered traffic flows from Battery and the Embarcadero. The horseshoe bar is most inviting, but Jamie W. and I were here with another couple to see if Michael Bauer's enthusiasm was justified. I started with a refreshing cocktail, the $10 Daredevil, a tantalizing, old-school mix of Campari, ginger beer and lemon (photo: bit.ly/1yTKg0b). We then shared a couple of no-risk options - the $7 Blistered Summer Peppers (photo: bit.ly/1AtUgjs) and the $8 Deviled Eggs (photo: bit.ly/XwKlf8). The peppers were mostly shishito and nicely roasted, while the quartet of egg halves were filled with yolks richly creamed with grain mustard and topped with crispy quinoa beads and a shard of bacon. Both starters gave a clear indication that the Fog was back, and it was full steam ahead. Entrees were all quite good, but two really stood out. Luckily I ordered the best one, the $35 Wood Oven Whole Chicken, which had me initially hesitant that the portion was too big. Alas, leftover chicken at home is fine by me, so I proceeded with the humongous, butterflied poultry that was laid before me in a piping-hot cast-iron skillet. It was in good company with whole fingerling potatoes, lightly smashed and heavily buttered, along with Brentwood corn on the cob, crisp bacon bits, kimchi butter, spiced salt and mixed greens (photo: bit.ly/1uQoX1X). The chicken was moist and tender with the skin crisped and smoked to an ideal state. It's almost as good as the roast chicken at Zuni Cafe, and you don't have to wait quite as long. Second prize went to the $31 Oak Grilled Pork Chop, quite a hefty, juicy bone-in slice that sat on top of sweet corn polenta, spicy collard greens and farmers' market stone fruit chutney (photo: bit.ly/1rQRJKS). Richly delicious. It was inevitable that the other two dishes paled by comparison. The $25 Wood Grilled Swordfish was tender, seasoned well and pleasing as it was nestled on top of a bed of roasted vegetables (photo: bit.ly/1pDqNzE), but overall it was a bit bland and vanilla in execution. The same could be said for the $19 Spice Roasted Wild Boar Ribs. They were a bit arid-tasting with just a dry rub seasoning and rather lonely with only the pickled celery, jalapeño, carrot and honey slaw to keep them company (photo: bit.ly/1mfNF3J). All of us were moving gradually into belt-loosening mode, but we knew we had to try at least a couple of their desserts. First up was their signature $6 Fog City Frozen Custard made with Straus Dairy cream. Tahitian vanilla bean was the flavor of choice and it came on top of a glazed French cruller with a dark chocolate sauce for an extra $2. But the winner was the $8 Strawberry Shortcake, a creamed biscuit topped with seascape strawberries and brown sugar-infused whipped cream (photo: bit.ly/VBlNzr). OK we're done now. Full. The Fog has lifted back to its original state of culinary grace. FOOD - 4 stars...back-to-basics American done up with flair with the whole chicken a major standout AMBIANCE - 4 stars...much more chic and relaxing than its previous iterations with roomy booths and scenic city scene views SERVICE - 3.5 stars...much more cordial than they were in the Diner days TOTAL - 4 stars...reinvented American bistro proves you can go home again

GvIyQN4UQUHxgBt6Ktdmnw.review_text: I've been to Fog City Diner a bunch of times, and a few times just recently.  I don't think I've ever had a bad experience here, and now that it's remodeled and has a great new layout/floor plan, I love it even more.    This last time I went, everything was so good, and our waiter, Mario, was pretty awesome, so I told him I would make sure to give him a great review on Yelp... heh.  Mario was extremely friendly (without being over the top), and made great drink recommendations (take his advice!), and was really on top of making sure everything was great.    On top of that, I've never been disappointed with Fog City's Bloody Mary (aka, the Bloody Devil)... it's SO GOOD!  I think it's weird that when it comes to deviled eggs anywhere else, I pretty much skip over them, thinking "Oh, old people food."  Yeah, not so much at Fog City... they're so ridiculously good, I literally ate 4 of them, as well as 2 more that topped the Bloody Devils I ordered.  I think I'm addicted now.  My only (mild) complaint is that I wish they had a slightly larger brunch selection, but I can't even be upset about their limited menu since everything I've had from it (and they change it semi-regularly, it seems) has been incredible.  So yeah... Fog City Diner is incredible, and if you can manage it, ask to be seated in Mario's section.  He'll make the experience even better.

gjfcfzrYZ0O1xINHtnQKiA.review_text: I must have passed this place a gazillion times and never gone in thinking that it was for special occasions.  Thus, I was glad to be surprised by the level of comfort provided by the food, staff and restaurant.  Although the oysters brightened my evening, the pork chop was the most tender and flavorful piece of meat that I've had in a long time.  Of course, I ended on a sweet note with their pumpkin brioche bread pudding with frozen custard.  Service was exceptional with their recommendations, friendliness and patience.  I'll be sure to come back more often.

F9Oe29UmuEeKTOxgDGCgEg.review_text: Went for lunch in order to try out the new, improved Fog City.  Have been to the  previous Fog City Diner many times and always liked it.  It had a good vibe and still does.  Ordered a Something Vodka and a Hot Brown.  Both were delicious; however, what really got my attention was the waitress and the exquisite service.  It was top notch and beyond expectation.  Yeah, $18 for an open-faced turkey sandwich is rather over the top, but so are most things in SF.  Nevertheless,  an enjoyable experience and will be longing to go back!

5ceueggjlopnvTfUkz-RYw.review_text: Short version :Overall food was just Ok.. Service was great and decor of restaurant was upgraded nicely was a bar in the middle and open window all around which brighten up the earthly feel of the place . Some items on the menu I feel was on the pricer side maybe due to the tourist attraction nearby .  Location : 2 blocks away from exploratorium ..   My friend made RSVP for 11:30 right when they opened so the place was pretty empty, even for Saturday morning brunch. The table was ready and set up for three of us next to the window looking out to the street ..u may request for table looking out to the Pier but there not much to see other than the new construction site on the pier.  Food:  Hand-cut Furikake Fries, Garlic Aioli   Original with a Japanese twist .. With flakes of seaweeds and Bonita. Liked.  F O G  C I T Y  Burger: my friend ordered it.. She enjoyed it .. Nothing extraordinary, but good juicy Burger .  The Spaceman : an non- alcoholic drink with Pomegranate, Lime, Honey, Tonic.. It was a pretty and sizzling drink . But I thought it was a bit pricy 6$ for non alcohol drink.  Panorama Bread: come in 3 piece.. It sourdough bread .. crispy on the outside and soft inside but for a  hip and modern restaurant I would expect it to be complimentary instead of charging 3$ for each piece.  F O G  C I T Y  Hot Brown 18$  House Roasted Heritage Turkey, Pt Reyes Cheddar Mornay Sauce, Crisp Bacon, Roma Tomatoes, Openface on Sourdough Bread.. I just thought it was A -ok.. Didn't have too much flavoring.. Tomatoe was rather bland..And turkey was rather dry. Beacon was only piece I enjoyed of the whole dish .  Would ask them for some hot sauce to add a kick to it .   Service was 5 stars .. Friendly waitress and often come back to check on us . And we did not felt rushed even though we sat there for almost 2 hours .

TpR8-mCpSZMd6VUbqUfMXQ.review_text: The wait service was very accommodating especially since our party of 7 also had 2 infants.  my dish (trout was delicious.  The swordfish was a bit dry,  Hamburgers were great. the short ribs were tender and delicious. And the lamb wraps were so so. For the most part it was a very positive experience.

3cqNRdls-hrj0V81ExaTTQ.review_text: We had a reservation on a Friday night at 7:30 PM!  It was too loud to carry on any sort of a reasonable conversation at our table.  Yes, the deviled eggs and chicken were good but the noise spoiled the festivities for our holiday party.

Bjz4TBIlyv6SBvYf5IOHBA.review_text: First of all, let me state for the record, although the location is the same and the name is similar, this is *NOT* the Fog City Diner.  The Fog City Diner is closed and gone.  This is a new restaurant called Fog City.  Accept the change.  If you want to go to Fog City Diner, get a time machine.  I'm very happy with the remodel of the space.  Yes, the old building was very cutting edge for its day, but it was really showing its age.  Plus the interior was very dark and not particularly inviting.  I remember people referring to getting a table on the Embarcadero side of the building as being in Siberia.  The new space is very open.  They took out the wall in the middle and opened up the Embarcadero side of the building with larger windows.  Once the America's cup structures are removed, that side of building will have a nice view of the bay.  I'd describe the decor as "industrial chic."  Clean and modern but comfortable.  We've eaten here four times now and have enjoyed everything we've eaten.  Even though they have "classic" items on their menu such as french fries and deviled eggs, they are done with a slightly different flair.  Their fries are served with Furikake and the eggs with quinoa and bacon.  Not perhaps what you might expect, but most enjoyable.  The pickles are wonderful!  For entrees we've tried the burger, pork cheeks, chicken, lamb and ribeye.  All were excellent.  Big enough to share if you'd care to.  I will say, however, that the pork cheeks are exceptionally rich.  We had it on our first "official" visit when we went a bit overboard with our ordering and it was just a bit too much on top of three appetizers and two vegetable courses prior.  For dessert, we've tried the frozen custard, crullers and panna cotta pudding cake.  All were amazing, but the crullers are transcendent.  We found the service to be excellent.  All of the staff we've met so far have been very friendly and helpful.  I'm not a drinker, but according to the SO, the bar does a great job.  As an aside, the SO dropped by for lunch within the past week without a reservation and although there was a bit of a wait, was accommodated within a reasonable amount of time.  We'll be back.

jdB-eFhvYeJXiazB01AmqQ.review_text: I would recommend the broccli, very good  The customer service could be stepped up a notch

RJezea2OzJh_L7beCDtlQQ.review_text: Soft opening on September 20 was amazing! Dustin (from Picco fame) is a great choice as CEM (Chief Executive Mixologist).   Come see the beautiful bar, enjoy creative cocktails and extraordinary culinary creations.

Bi9pwJu-wpNU_darEkROaQ.review_text: The place looks wonderful and is located right next to a beautiful view on the pier of both bridges and the water. The service is absolutely phenomenal and the presentation of food looks great!  However, the recipe and taste of food didn't match the standards set by their location and aesthetics. The menu looked great, but as we got down to the food, there were too many inconsistencies. Sometimes it would be a little too dry, or too salty and saucy, or it felt like the chef forgot an ingredient. It was displeasing.   We still had a great time nonetheless. However, boring food is a 3 star to me. I would wish this place stepped it up, because its seabreeze location to one of the best spots of the pier and its proximity to the Coit Tower make it a great place to take a date out.

PRw12Yx-c-U5UsywjKS1oA.review_text: I loved my visit to Fog City!   It was my first time there and we were greeted by a very friendly hostess arriving a bit before our reservation.  We sat at the bar for a cocktail and app to wait for our table, but were so comfortable at the bar we decided to stay there for our meal.  Great service, the food was great, loved sharing small plate dishes. A very cool place with a nice vibe - will definitely go there again. See my complete review of the food with photos on my blogsite at delish-dish.com/steeped-…!

3nPw1uhSLDDhq1YeLrMUxA.review_text: Haven't been to Fog City for 15 years, so I was pleasantly surprised to go back and not only not recognize the place but love the new look and ambiance. Food coming out of the open kitchen looked and smelled fabulous. We only had the steak taco and the chicken salad but along with the atmosphere loved it!!
