Terrific bar tenders and actually the same warm entertaining feeling you get when you are at the sister restaurants Bungalow44 and Buckeye. Will definitely go back soon when in the city!

WzgTJg1cWYsFMCZKLHd8-w.review_text: Such an improvement from the previous Fog City Diner.   Great place to share plates.  We had the cauliflower, deviled eggs, roasted chicken and swordfish for 4 to share. Perfect portion. The chicken tasted like Thomas Keller's roasted chicken recipe.  The fish was a little dry, but was perfectly fine eaten with the white beans and cherry tomatoes.  The appetizers, just fabulous. They do charge for dessert if you bring in your own. I think it's $3 a person, or per dessert.    The service is a little slow, and a little forgetful.  But not a complete deal breaker.   Coming back for a date night.

u2InCKrEHxk3CPTO3ig9NA.review_text: I hadn't eaten at The Fog City Diner for what had to have been 15+ years--way before a recent renovation in decor and menu. The food, in general, was good, fresh, and healthy, but what ruined the experience was the poor service.   After being seated, we didn't see our waiter for at least 10 minutes and our drinks for another 10 minutes. My wife and I both ordered the salmon which I thought was delicious but proved to be somewhat undercooked for her. When she told the waiter it was too raw for her, rather than offer to take it back to the kitchen and put it under the broiler for another 2-3 minutes, he questioned her taste and told her that this was how the restaurant prepares the dish.   Once he finally took it back to the kitchen for some further preparation, we didn't see him again for another 10 minutes by which time the salmon was cooked but cold, I had already finished my meal, and our mood had darkened.  What we hoped would be a nice dinner turned into a real disappointment.   The food at Fog City Diner was good and there were lots of attractive dishes to choose from. But our waiter seemed overtaxed with too many tables to service, and once there was a little problem, he became irritated and his attitude became really poor.    Maybe we'll try it again in 15 years.

RhUQ1Vz3-bDMLbIGlcyzfA.review_text: The new Fog City is a reasonable re-take on Cindy Pawlcyn's venerable establishment, but doesn't yet offer enough to draw city dwellers to the waterfront.  Upon entering, diners are treated to a welcoming, open dining room.  Gone is the jarring chrome; accented with warm wood, the new sophisticated space helps assure diners that they are not in yet another Embarcadero tourist trap.  Having earned his chops at Stars, Aqua, Oritalia, and Waterfront Restaurant, Chef Bruce Hill offers a menu based on live fire cooking and fresh, local ingredients.   Deviled eggs ($6) with crispy quinoa and bacon are a great starter.  Served on a house-made bun with smoked tomato aioli, American cheese, tomato, onion, and bread and butter pickles, the Fog City burger ($14) is a contender for the top ten (OK, maybe 20) burgers in The City.  Served with charred Brentwood corn and crispy potatoes and topped with spiced Maldon salt, the whole wood oven roasted chicken ($24) was good, but not up to the level of Zuni Café.  The French fries ($6) with furikake seasoning and garlic aioli were undercooked and limp--a disappointing side note to an otherwise solid performance.  There is an ever-changing selection of 16 wines on tap, as well as an extensive list of wines by the bottle. With seven beers on tap and numerous other offerings by the bottle, the beer program features artisanal selections, from both local and national breweries.  Service was friendly and well-meaning, but a little off.  Courses were not well paced: entrées arrived before appetizers were finished, and servers were sometimes absent for extended periods.  With a little more innovation on the menu and some investment in staff training, the new Fog City could once again hope to draw City dwellers to the waterfront.

gekp2Z5I4vPGf2NeFnZX2A.review_text: The 4 of us got a nice comfy booth for 6 for our Sunday brunch. We started with the donuts which were hot sugary and delicious. The kale salad appetizer was a good combination of soft goat cheese, crunchy nuts and hearty kale. The dressing was light and perfect. The oysters were not very meaty but the flavors of the mignonette complemented them perfectly. We decided that the winning main course was the hot brown. And boy was it hot!!! Scolding hot! The $17 chicken soup was great but the roasted brussels sprouts took over the flavor. I would have called it Brussels sprout soup. Two of us got the burger and both loved it. The bun should have been warmed. They said the burger is served medium. But we both agreed it was medium rare. My friend likes it medium rare so that was perfect for him. Our waiter Adam had the patience of a saint.

NgKm99u4c7MH53EVCZhCtQ.review_text: I had the Saigon Dip, which was good but I not the best meal of all time. Easy location nice interiors but the prices are very high! A sandwich for $18 is a bit steep and it didn't come with any salad, garnish or fries only broth to dip the sandwich in, the plate looked a little empty. I feel that this place is a bit pricey and the food was just good/ok not mind blowing. There are so many places in the city to eat so I may never come back , or at least I wouldn't make a effert to come back... but if a friend wanted to go or I was starving in the area I would go in again.

M271Ac7UKVaQ9U5AOvc_9A.review_text: Peace, love, brussels sprouts, rapini, ribs, roasted chicken, and ALL THE DESSERTS, especially the panna cotta pudding cake.  Add a side of furikake fries, and you're all set.  Cannot go wrong.  Especially when you're at a place that serves donuts and frozen custard for dessert, duh.

0t-O5--DOfS55A620fO_GA.review_text: I'm pretty loyal to Fog City because it's only 2 blocks from my house :)  I sincerely  enjoy both dinners and happy hours here!    Atmosphere:  The vibe is great!  I've taken several out of town visitors here and they have certainly enjoyed their visit here as well.  The friendly bartenders and hostesses are always very sweet to me.  I've never had to wait long for a drink or to be seated.    Happy Hour:  from 4-6 on Monday - Friday a slight discount is offered on drinks.  I wish the discounts were greater on food and drink here during happy hour, but I get it-- with the wharf nearby and a constant flow of tourist traffic Fog City probably doesn't NEED to offer happy hour.  Drinks:  The handcrafted cocktail menu has something for everyone and the wine list has great options as well.    Food:  The small plate menu changes with the seasons, which helps to keep the menu fresh for frequent visitors like me! There are some great snack options like paprika peanuts, farm beets, deviled eggs, and calamari.  The dinner menu has great options too.  My favorite dinners have been the burger and the short ribs.  Brunch options are available on Saturday and Sunday beginning at 11:30 a.m.  I hope to be back soon to try brunch!

sFuzusspts5lJGREsmAl0w.review_text: So disappointing. I was really excited to try the new menu. Space is beautifully updated. I was expecting the same of the menu.  I've been there twice hoping the last visit would be better than first one. I had the Saigon dip and the much raved about salmon smorrebrod as well as the furikake fries. All were disappointing. Best items in my meal - Brussels sprouts with Asian pear and panama cotta pudding cake.

ZNX66SIyH8Fq1E1udWT9XA.review_text: The Hot Brown is the best thing I have eaten in my entire life. That is all.

g0QiXdDjT7gtEzsV5VEqaA.review_text: We were hungry on our walk to Fishermans Wharf and came across this place. The service was great and the food was tasty. We had the Saigon Dip and the Aioli Burger. Both were super tasty. It was way to warm inside, but it was a nice day so we were able to enjoy sitting outside.

e_pKXqrLvCeFgrU2vc_O_A.review_text: Nice setting, good food but definitely don't let the waiter order for you!!! There were 5 of us and we were served way too much food including 5 crab cakes @ $8 each so 1 of 4 starters was $40. Then 2 salads, 2 vegetables and 2 entrees. It was also strange that he served a 3rd bottle of wine while the 4 of us drinking still had glasses half full. We inquired why he opened a third bottle when we didn't request it and it was taken away. All in all, I would return as the food was tasty however it was an unpleasant feeling to have trusted the waiter and left feeling his objective was perhaps not in our best interest...

0mpTe93g-ENH4mXvkev-jA.review_text: Had to visit this former classic which is just steps from my home. Looks like it will be a winner! Friendly welcome by Tyler and crew. Great, attentive service. Nice decor -- a good-looking redo. The restaurant was packed when we arrived and seemed to be uber-noisy. As the evening progressed, things quieted down, but maybe something could be done to offer some sound buffering. Food was tremendous. Had the deviled eggs (great), the Halibut crudo (nice), the Furikake fries with aioli (ordered a second one, since they were so good), the hamburger (had to -- that was a favorite at the old Fog City Diner -- this one is different, and good), the roast chicken (great), the fig salad (wonderful), and for dessert the French crullers (very good), and the custard with egg caramel sauce (liked the unusual sauce -- didn't taste the custard). I'll be back to try some of the other small plates, that's for sure.

QzPaoBVAshV-aodtcd1A4g.review_text: We live in the neighborhood and were very anxious to check out the Fog City revamp.  Had a visit on Halloween night and we were not disappointed. I love the redesigned layout of the space. Its cozy and inviting. Love the smell of the wood fired oven as you walk in the door. Everything is open including the kitchen. And its nice to see the city moving by out the large windows.  They have several wines by the glass available on tap. The prices are nice range of "something for everyone" in style and price. I didn't have a cocktail, but the list looked pretty inviting.  We ordered the butter lettuce salad with a smoky green goddess dressing. Plenty for two of us to share. It was a very tasty salad. I'd like to put it up against the green goddess salad at Wayfare Tavern. Not sure who would win that fight.  Shared some brussels sprouts with asian pear and ponzu that had been fired in the wood oven. Must confess they didn't last very long. Can't wait to have them again soon.  For the main course we shared the pork cheeks with romano beans and polenta. Pork cheeks were fork tender and just crispy on the edges with a delicate sauce that didn't overpower a thing. Pure heaven in this dish. Creamy crispy fresh and plenty for two to share.  I had read amazing things about the dessert so we ordered the crullers and the frozen custard with egg yolk caramel. I was transported back to college days of a shop that served hot doughnuts to hungry students in the midwest. Only Fog City's had the most lovely orange scented glaze. Fresh, hot and light yet crispy.   The frozen custard was delivered as  scoop in a dish, with a tiny pitcher of caramel on the side. Their salty rich creamy caramel paired with rich frozen custard is pretty hard to beat. Even better when you dip your cruller into each item.  The service was very warm and inviting. I can't wait to go back for another visit. We officially have a new neighborhood favorite!

uu8bm14q7wO4BTeeoZKgdg.review_text: Cocktails and open face sandwiches near Fisherman's Wharf. #sanfrancisco #restaurantreview  Recommend oysters, which come prepared with a cocktail sauce and herbs, and the salmon sandwich with avocado, egg salad and dill. Sandwiches come open face and in pairs. Get two types and split. Fries have seaweed and sesame seed and are perfectly crispy.   Service was subpar, which is why this gets knocked down a half star. 3.5 star rating.

FFLoCgg7ljYV5fkfhpCNMg.review_text: Lovely restaurant. Great decor, wonderful service, delicious thoughtful menu. Then I noticed "4% SF offset" added to the bill. I asked the manager. Apparently that is a surcharge added due to the cost of business for being in San Francisco. I have NEVER seen anything like that. If you can't run your restaurant in an area, then don't. It was rude. It was like being charged cover. It would be better to hide that cost within the price of food.

_OWteEa1PTAb2p_tp4Op9Q.review_text: My hunt for a great SF burger continues, because this was not it. They brag about the unique way it's prepared -thin- but it seems that thin means flavorless. Not that different from in-n-out, except for how the meat was raised, and though that's important to me, the flavor is also paramount.

KqXtP34tqVH53FVVuzcPcQ.review_text: I and my friend randomly walked by and decided to give this place a try! The experience turned out surprisingly great! We ordered Cauliflower nuggets, furikake fries ( 5 stars for this fries!!), and Berkshire pork cheeks. These food portions were enough to feed two persons. I was very happy with the pork cheeks with mushrooms. Very tender and very well cooked. Really good service there as well. I will definitely wanna go back. It's a perfect spot for a dinner date.

qLZnWeAlykOzTF__vvrbbQ.review_text: I feel it was just another Joes of Westlakes. An older crowd, Food was meh.  Def on the expensive side.

dEN7NVBaBIOAWQMsXwyEiA.review_text: Again, I love  this place.  Around the corner.  Ordered the whole chicken dish, so much food, needed to bring home.  Fries are ridiculous, along with curry cauliflower. As far as drinks...we love the Fog City mule with Bitter Girl Bitters (ask for it)   I like to compare it with High West Distillerys  Mule in Park City, we spend a lot of time there..I like Fog City's  the best now.

DUnOMxkxsSv-WetQDRn0OA.review_text: You know, before the renovation, I loved everything about this diner. It was nice, well designed setup, had a very lovely interior, amazing food.... Not to mention, I always sat in the booth that was featured in my favorite movie "So I Married an Axe Murderer" featuring Mike Myers; this EASILY was my favorite diner in all San Francisco. But I have to say this last time after the remodeling/re-opening.... It went downhill. I felt like everything tasted the same: like it was drenched in the same vat of uncomplimentary spices... I know they have to compete with other trendy businesses... But they couldn't keep ONE thing from the previous menu?? Not even the seafood salad?? And I have to say... The lamb kabobs: don't waste your time with these. They're not authentic. They don't really taste that great at all....  I do have to say I liked the Brussel sprouts... And the deviled eggs were... Alright. Not epic.  Now. Another thing: WE WERE SNUBBED. BY THE FREAKING MAÎTRE DE. And our waitress wasn't gonna win the Miss Congeniality title anytime soon.  I'm sorry to say that, unless they lower the prices on the sub-par food (or create a better menu!), the staff check their attitudes, and they bring back a hint of the old place, we won't be going back any time soon.   I hope this review helps someone out.  :)

y091U7mHl54NhreZmoCE-A.review_text: My husband and I had previously had many delicious meals at the old Fog City Diner during its heyday and had many wonderful memories of its warm and inviting interior and service during that time. So, we were really looking forward to having brunch at the recently reopened Fog City. Our interpretation of brunch is that there are lunch dishes along with several egg dishes on the menu. However, this was not the case. There was one egg dish (eggs benny). Having had many great burgers at the original diner, my husband thought that he couldn't go wrong by ordering the Fog City Cheese Burger. It was nothing like the juicy thick burgers that good SF restaurants serve. The patty was about ¼" thick with the rest of the bun being taken up with onions and chopped lettuce. Definitely not worth $14, especially when you can go to The Burritt Tavern and get a great burger for a bit less. I had a dish called the Fog City Hot Brown (turkey, Mornay sauce, tomatoes on rye) for $16. It wasn't horrible, but it was very boring, with the sauce overpowering any other taste. A strip of bacon was put on top even though it wasn't on the menu, maybe to try to add taste. Anyway, there's not much positive that I can say about the food or the ambience of the new Fog City.

TpZN51jtAZTu7BjYxTfpjA.review_text: Newly renovated, this place doesn't really look or taste like a diner anymore. A streamline bar runs down the center. It has gorgeous windows that overlook the Embarcadero. Their plates are fantastic for sharing. We enjoyed the deviled eggs as an appetizer and they really are amazing just as everyone on yelp said. I really enjoyed the crispy bacon and quinoa mixed in with the soft egg. Don't let the word fried deter you from the yummy mini artichokes. They are excellently cooked and the garlic aioli dip is yummy. We shared the special fish of the day which was a wonderful swordfish. It was more than enough food for the two of us.    Make sure to save room for a dish of their very yummy Fog City Custard. Its creamier than ice cream but more flavorful than frozen yogurt.

QRXprpL3ZYqYWOce3HiX4A.review_text: This is my absolutely favorite place to eat in the Bay Area. I LOVE THIS PLACE!!!! Friendly staff and great food! Well priced! The catch of the day is always well prepared and changes regularly to keep things interesting!

TjUUhGaci0Ye9vWoviFJ5Q.review_text: Went there last night for their Grand Opening. The overall décor and makeover is lovely! The design of the new location gives it a fresh and crisp look. The chairs were comfortable and the lighting was just right. I was a little disappointed by the menu since I called to make a reservation and asked how the menu has changed and was told that the chef has changed and that the food is more refined but that some of the elements from the previous restaurant were kept. We were a table of 3 and all of us felt that the menu was lacking those comforting elements it used to have in the past. Since we had a fish allergy in our table the menu was very limited and we all felt that it was hard to choose.  I must say that the items we did choose were all well prepared. We started off with the pickles which reminded me of my grandma's pickles. They were great however the portion was a little too small. We then had the Fries. The aioli that came with the fries was wonderful. We also ordered the girl tomato salad which was wonderful. I think that out of everything we ordered I enjoyed this dish the most. The tapenade dressing was salty and creamy at the right texture. There was just enough of it in the salad.  We also ordered a side of bread and the bread was hot and really hard to cut in portions. We ended up having to tear it apart with our hands since we couldn't slice it appropriately. All three of us had the hamburger prepared to different degrees of doneness. The one thing which is hard to do is share a hamburger so I would think it's not a sharable item and would not present it as such. The homemade bun, although good in flavor was too thin and the aioli on the bottom made it soggy and impossible to eat as a hamburger. I had to use a knife and fork to dismantle my burger... The burger flavor was really good and the pickles that went with it gave it a sweeter flavor which was interesting. We were excited about the desserts and ordered the frozen custard, the curled donuts and the pana cotta chocolate caramel cake. The frozen custard had a great texture but we did not care so much for the dark chocolate sauce that came with it. It had a processed flavor to it. The chocolate sauce did help the donuts a lot. I like the presentation of the donuts and thought it was a nice way to present something so simple. The donuts themselves were nice and fluffy but a sauce on the side to accompany it would really help. (we used the sauce that came with the custard) The highlight of the desserts was by far the pana cotta chocolate caramel cake. The mixture of flavors, the saltiness of the cake and the caramel were so complimentary to one another. Overall an ok experience. Good food execution. A few comments on the side:  We found that the menu was vague in description. 2 of the 3 people in our group are restaurant people (work in kitchens) and the descriptions were so hard to understand that we had to ask a lot of questions. Unfortunately, our waiter tried unsuccessfully to answer those questions for us but had a really hard time describing them in any other way.  With regards to the dessert menu we found that the frozen custard was not clear on how it really worked out and how it was presented.  The curly donuts also had a weird description for them and that was not something we were clear about either. The pana cotta also had these key words but it wasn't clear how a cake and pana cotta were combined into a dessert together. The waiter did manage to describe this dish in a good manner. We all know that yesterday was opening night. We are giving this feedback in the hope that some of our comments will be heard and hopefully dealt with so that we can continue coming to this establishment many more times in the future. The restaurant does have tremendous potential and we will definitely give it another shot in a few months.

vBxiTBwtVBRAGGRmJZccCA.review_text: I went there for dinner last night and the food was just ok, the service was less than ok, and the prices were quite high for what you get. I will say their cocktails were amazing, but that is the only thing I would recommend here.   We paid $3 for some bread (seriously??) because we were starving. We also ordered some fries before our entrees, and they were cooked in some sort of fish oil that made them taste VERY fishy. That was kind of an unpleasant surprise.   Instead of just refilling our water, our server reminded us there is a drought in California and asked if we thought we would drink all our water if he refilled them. Again... Seriously?  We told him he didn't have to refill them, but then he never came back to offer us another drink.  I just think that you can find better food, service, and prices at many other restaurants in the city. Try Cotogna instead of this-- you will be much happier.

w365A5I8BMBjjlf5qFrKTw.review_text: great new place .. so much better than the old diner. Bright new feel, bartender was great! recommended special drinks and wine to pair with the tasting menu.  great service, even picked up on the impress the date, vibe

VgtcRwMPiAEeuPsayXB4kA.review_text: The "bloody devil" is their take on the bloody Mary, garnished with one of their amazing deviled eggs. Loved it. The banana bread french toast is ridiculously delicious. The dungeness crab benedict and the chorizo hash were both great, though perhaps a tad underseasoned (better than being too salty, I'll admit). The maple glazed donuts were outstanding. Great service, nice ambiance...except for that random robot art by the restrooms.

oygf5Gqc1MY2crhNPVBaZw.review_text: Everything was so delicious. Mac and cheese is a must, had the whole chicken, oh my lanta was it good! Amaizing service, warm ambiance. Defiantly will be coming here again

X46RumEcunbgY_j6Rq1FfA.review_text: Oh boy where do I start?? There are so many things to say about this "San Francisco institution". From the service to the food to the check, what a taxing and tacky experience.   The hostess apparently didn't appreciate me asking for a booth when we arrived at the EMPTY restaurant on Sunday, July 27th at 5pm. When I requested to sit at booth she responded "is there anything else you're going to ask me for?"  The waitstaff was slow, unapologetic for the cold soup, and dirty spoon, and not once did we get the impression that we were guests.   Horrible experience, way overpriced for the bland and cold food. We will never be back and we deliver a warning to those who look forward to going - this place is a disgrace. Don't waste your time or money

bl2JJL3Yxc5OVdHSJeoohA.review_text: This is only the 23rd rating of five stars that I've given to an American restaurant, but it is most assuredly worth it.  (The original Fog City Diner was the fourth restaurant that I've rated with five stars).   While my wife and I loved going to the original Fog City Diner, I was a bit skeptical of the new (updated) restaurant.  I was not disappointed!  The food is absolutely magnificent, superlative, and does not merit any criticism of the menu items I've tried thus far.  Every patron that I've seen in the restaurant enjoyed the food and themselves immensely.  The wines, beer and cocktails were excellent: if you are not a oenophile,  I highly recommend asking your server to suggest or recommend a wine to be paired with your entree.  Their wines are excellent and unlike most restaurants, where getting wine by the glass most often has little to recommend, this is one place where I would heartily recommend ordering wine by the glass if you so choose.  The service was excellent and so was the staff, who I found to be genuinely very personable -- and not just to earn a large gratuity.  They have all been delightfully helpful, gracious, delightfully patient (the restaurant was packed; there was a long wait for a table, people were hungry and the time between ordering and being served was, as you might expect, proportional for the number of people seated, yet both our server and host stopped by the table to see if we could be served in any way as we sat waiting).  I've always brought my closest friends, associates, and professional colleagues here without the slightest hesitation (despite language challenges of many of my foreign colleagues).    Every item on the menu is well-worth trying.  For those who are new to the restaurant, I highly recommend asking the host or your server to make a recommendation for your lunch or dinner, and -- by all means -- ask for their recommendation of a wine to pair with your entree.  There has only been one person who did not know which wine he'd recommend and asked another server to suggest a wine for me: I deeply appreciated their honesty and candor.  (I travel an average of 318 days a year to 79 different countries, and dine out approximately 350 days a year.  I enjoy passing my impressions of restaurants' food, wines, service, and value to my friends.  Fog City is one of my favorite restaurants, and one that I love bringing family, friends, visitors, and professional colleagues here, for the food is that good.)  Last of all: a patron, in a review, made comment about being treated poorly on the basis of race.  I wouldn't tolerate this for a New York second, personally or professionally.  In the 26 years I've been a guest at Fog City Diner, to include the new Fog City restaurant, I have never seen even the slightest suggestion of racism on the part of any restaurant employee.  (As I have been employed by airlines, I would never tolerate such treatment even if I observed it in dealings of the staff with other customers and would never risk bring a professional colleague to this restaurant if I ever had a question or concern about racism.)  After reading the one negative review which cited racism in their experience, having patronized this restaurant an average of perhaps twice monthly over the better part of 25 years, I've never experienced, observed, or been told of such an allegation -- and question why the individuals involved didn't seek out the manager or owner, if they felt so strongly about their alleged treatment to include an allegation of racism in a review.

M8o7d4Zqeev3PGSHZeu8zA.review_text: One of the WORST dining experiences I've ever had---and I used to manage a restaurant in The City. Situation: my son's 11th birthday. Party of 5. We had a reservation: waited 20 minutes for a table. Service: waited over an hour for the food after we had purposely pre-ordered the chicken while waiting for our table because we were told it would take 35 minutes. Waitress was snotty and condescending, telling us how the chef recommends we order each dish (yes I get that the steak should be cooked med-rare but let's not have an argument with my boyfriend about ordering it med-well.) Food: mediocre at best. Chicken was dry. $39 steak was ok but 1/3 fat. Everything was bland. Nothing special here. Management: once we complained about our food taking so long the manager was barely concerned and seemed to hover around our table afterward hoping we would leave. We were completely rushed through our meal and suddenly had 3 bussers constantly trying to clear plates. My son's desert wasn't even comped! Bottom line: I'm a disgruntled native San Franciscan that is continuously disappointed in what this town has become. Fog City Diner used to be a place where you could have a good meal with your family. There are hardly any places like that anymore. But that's another tangent. Warning on this douchey restaurant. Spend your money somewhere else.

4RAXTHLtE0L2wwVVBJ2Iyw.review_text: I have been meaning to try out the newly opened diner as it's near where I work and I'm always looking for new lunch spots. I sat at the bar as lunch was going to be a quick affair today. Bar hostess was very pleasant and the decor very tastefully contemporary. OK, to the menu, sorta weird mix of stuff but I plump for the standard diner fair of a burger. First off I do not get asked how I would like my burger cooked, not a problem I guess. Then I get asked if I want fries, OK I guess you get a choice of fries or salad? Up comes my burger, pattie looks a little small and it's VERY rare, I don't mind that but many don't and would have had to send it back. Tastes OK but how hard is it to f*ck a burger up? I finish my meal and ask for the check, are you kidding me! The burger was $14, but wait the fries were an extra $6!!! Tax and tip see me coughing up $26.40 for a very average burger and fires. WAY OVER PRICED!  I will not be returning unless someone else is buying.

5yFZe3tCCjLJhcWNg32Dng.review_text: I loved the old Fog City Diner. But the new and improved version is quite acceptable! No more Mac and Cheese on the menu, but the new menu is fantastic. Had the grilled fig salad, and it was exceptional. The bacon and quinoa devil eggs were so good, that I could have eaten them the whole night. I ordered the lamb skewers and my husband had the steak. Both were absolutely delicious. We were very pleased with our meal and would recommend it highly to anyone.

MnGIHcYOFI1NMIc0OHCYfw.review_text: Enjoyed a perfect brunch at Fog City today.  I had the Albacore Tuna Salad  ($17) with Butter Lettuce, Grilled Pole Beans, Early Girl Tomatoes, Black Garlic Miso Vinaigrette and crispy little Onions.  It was a perfect blend of flavors and, paired with the barrel Pinot Noir, made for a great meal.  My partner had the Smoked Salmon Smørrebrød and a barrel red blend with which he was equally enamored.  Service and ambiance were both without complaint.

fDv4S41fLwO9_xPNm53e1A.review_text: A great remodel of the venue and a great new menu. The beef tongue was wonderful - something you don't see except in burritos in SF. The chile apple pie was also extraordinary. This is an excellent reinvention of what had been tourist fodder for the last 10 years.

srj-v0WSYa-1gpmffbeypg.review_text: My partner & I came here twice for dinner, the last time being this evening.  What a beautiful job they did remodeling the rather tired diner!  We were seated both times at the bar with soft light from below illuminating it.  The bar is located in the middle of the restaurant, with one side facing the open kitchen.  What an exciting sight to behold when all the kitchen staff is working furiously, yet in harmony, when the restaurant was packed, as it was 2 Fridays ago.  It wasn't quite as busy tonight but it's still nice to see folks seemingly enjoying their work and the easy banter they were having.    But, really, the food is THE lure.  So far, we've tried about  1/2 of their dishes between the 2 visits.  My personal highlights are: the clams, just a mélange of flavors with broth that almost made me weep when I accidentally dripped some on the counter; the grilled beef tongue, chunky pieces of such tender meat with great accompaniment of mushroom and greens and; roasted duck leg, with meat completely falling off the bones, and plums & arugula cutting through the fattiness of the dish.  The dishes that I probably will not order again are: the kampachi crudo, just too subtle of a dish to stand a chance on this menu: grilled spiced lamb skewer, just not special enough to stand out from what I could get in a Middle Eastern eatery for far less cost.  We live close by and have eaten often at the diner version over the years.  The last few times have been a shadow of their Glory years and I am happy that this new version is here to reclaim their reputation.

0Vng_7e5dYu994O_vl2sIQ.review_text: Really great redux of a San Francisco classics IMHO.  The drinks were a great start, and the apps were wonderful.  We started with the Fries and Calamari, both super delicious.  Then on to the chicken ( a must and definitely shareable) and ribs.  All of the flavors and sides completed each other so very well.   Not sure why anyone would give this place a bad review. Service was on point and the energy of the place is great too.   We would definitely return.

EAE76VAose-LQTmbr0Cu0A.review_text: The reason I gave a three is because the food is overpriced. That being said what I had was good overall.   I had the dog city burger which was very yummy, the fries which were ok, and the strawberry shortcake which was good but would try something else next time.   The workers were very nice and attentive and the ambiance is pleasing.

Bp6kCG0W9BV2oa2XhumKkA.review_text: We stumbled across this little gem while tourist walking the Embarcadero on our way to the UW vs BYU Fight Hunger Bowl at ATT.   I found it on yelp as a good spot for brunch near our Fisherman's Wharf hotel. (Aren't we trendy). I decided we need good cocktails at brunch obviously.   First off this place is gorgeous. I mean stunningly pretty. Open kitchen, low booths, huge windows. We got stuffed in the back(Hungover, Hungry, guys in sports apparel don't deserve to sit where decent members of society can see them) and still had a nice view.  We popped in around 11 for some brunch. Dressed head to toe in Husky Gear, hungover, we looked slightly out of place. The wait staff didn't bat an eye, we were kindly addressed, seated, and served. Our waitress even put up with our lame attempts to flirt and be funny with a smile and occasional laugh. Service was excellent, she even let our most hungover patron order a grilled cheese off of the kids menu.  The cocktails were superb, I had the "Inside Job", a little rye for spice, ginger for the stomach, and lemon to wake you up. The Furikake Fries were mind blowing the fries were perfectly cooked the aioli was spot on and the furikake was a genius addition. I had the "Hot brown" as my entree. Everything was delicious but the dish lacked cohesiveness which I would blame on the composition. Nothing crumbling the bacon wouldn't fix.  I'll be back for the fries and cocktails without a doubt.

XIbwfLm5PtXnhgu3Q0zE-w.review_text: Decent place to visit when you are around the Pier and fancy yourself a drink.  They do have some good appetizer options but for me the prices are definitely higher than what they should be.  If they tempered their prices a little bit I might bump it into the 4 star range but the decent service compared with the overrated prices dropped it down a peg for me. It's a nice place and one I would go back to once in a blue moon but not something I would crave and visit on a consistent basis.

ByjLWqN_86o01bapf0etWQ.review_text: Really disappointing. What ISN'T wrong with this place?  I really expected a lot better from this well-known restaurant group reopening such an iconic San Francisco restaurant. Sadly, it seems someone there must think their fine reputation puts them above basic customer service.  Had New Years Day late lunch here today and, ok, it was New Years Day, so maybe management didn't staff for a HOLIDAY (?!) or somebody didn't show up for their shift...but the restaurant wasn't particularly busy, maybe half full, so why such a mess?  The service was a completed disaster - like I said, maybe they were understaffed or hung-over and movin' slow. Once we were seated, it took ten minutes for someone to come by and offer us water. We could see there were only two or three servers working the floor so decided what we wanted quickly and ordered from the server when she brought our water since it was clear we might not see her again for awhile.  I ordered the burger and asked for it medium-well, the server paused for a moment and answered "We can cook it medium OR well." **Um, really?** You can't cook a burger the way your guest prefers it? For a $14 burger (sans fries, which are another $7!!) you'd think they could cook it to order. Apparently not.  We ordered a kale salad that never arrived, so when the server brought the check I reminded her that and asked if it had been removed from the check. She responded yes, and that it was her fault, "I just didn't key it in." OMG.  It took 20 minutes for our iced teas to arrive and forty minutes for our food to come. About 10 minutes after we got our food (delivered by a different server, which made me think there is some sort of a service gap in doing it this way) our original server came by to ask if everything was ok. The water carafe on our table was empty, so I asked if we could have more water. She said yes, "In a minute." Wha??   I watched a group of guys sitting adjacent to us as their food came sporadically and having some issue with not getting what they ordered. )-:  Food was pretty good (and came to our table hot!)  but COMPLETELY overshadowed by the totally frustrating service and steep prices.   So many great restaurants in SF, spend your precious time and money at those, not here.

Yka_J40u_Bl7IW0R0Y3D_Q.review_text: When we find a place that's casual yet provides a superb dining experience; accommodates the kids without sacrificing anything from the adult experience, it goes "on the tour". The Fog City Diner is on the tour.

RRifrriRW8HB5wz3yoBKpw.review_text: It is way way way expensive for a quick lunch, but the food was delicious.  I got an open faced salmon sandwich and my friend got a burger.  Garlic fries were AMAZING and food was yummy, not sure if it was $50 yummy, but it was yummy none the less.

mzaRUvxcAWjPt-EDT6FwPQ.review_text: I went in the afternoon in a friday and it was devine! I had the grilled kale salad on the small plate portion of the menu. Definitely more of a medium salad it was nice and light the almonds were a nice ending note highly suggest!

v3sM7qB9iIn5u3l40dQ_Sw.review_text: Bravo! Deviled eggs! Chicken! Service! Decor! LOVE IT!!!

jp8zjspsEicyXWEa9gPzYQ.review_text: We came here for lunch today. Overall the place has a nice atmosphere. You know, 'nice', as in 'not really worthy of any other adjective nice'.   The kitchen is open, so you can see the chefs at work, but there's not the sizzle that you get in other open kitchens. There doesn't seem to be much energy about the place at all. Service wasn't slow, exactly. There just wasn't any gusto, you know?  Most of the food was underwhelming. I had the crab cakes, which were tasty but small. OK, they were on the menu as a 'small plate', but at $16 they were disappointing. My fiance had the chicken salad which was $17--extortionate, considering it was brown chicken meat and lettuce with a minimal amount of all the other ingredients (Tory Farm Nectarines, Marinated Cabbage, Candied Peanuts). Personally, I find it BAFFLING how restaurants can charge such high prices for what is, essentially, 10 cents worth of lettuce and less chicken than you get in a single chicken tender from KFC. Ridiculous.  Overall, 'meh' is a great word to describe Fog City. It's a shame, because it could be more upbeat, be  much better value for money and have more personality/individuality. But being where it is (right near the Pier buildings and near a constant stream of tourist traffic) the owners probably don't think they need to bother making any extra effort.

ohy_E0yQSfD6cslBuQLRLA.review_text: Really good food and nice ambiance.  Service was pleasant and the waiter was attentive but I can't stand when they take away someones dish while everyone else is still eating so I can't give them a 5.

LU7ikPXZ5R8tv4oNQZQkKw.review_text: The food is better than the original fog city diner but its pretty expensive.  I live across the street and I won't be back.  pwned

T8zZZK_ZEbjkV98J0m9qzw.review_text: Love the new Fog City; open space, modern yet comfy, upscale and reasonably priced!  Came for lunch today and since we had no reservation, we sat at the bar.  Nice, not crammed in and still able to have a nice conversation with my husband without interference or noise.    We ordered the burger, fries and brussel sprouts.  Service was excellent but the food was over the top delish!  Burger was cooked to perfection and was melt in your mouth juicy.  Fries with that aioli were amazing and I can't say enough about the sprouts in ponzu.  I have never enjoyed sprouts without bacon but I cleaned the bowl on those they were that good!      We don't get to the city often, but I'm dreaming of the next time just so we can dine here!

Sj7HxTlCJB0UF4vdTQdAUA.review_text: I've been there pre-renovation and post-renovation, and I can definitely say that they've done a great job with the new place. I had the kale salad and added chicken to it, which was both filling and healthy. My friends had the crab cake, which was somewhat mediocre.   I had the tequila old fashioned and thought it was interesting, but would rather have the whisky version.   Service was very good and the only reason it gets 4 stars is due to the price point. It's a little overpriced, but somewhat understandable for the Embarcadero / financial district.

BSw9btlZIxMNsc9VB52GnA.review_text: Ordered a burger and received what looked like a burger from the frozen section of a discount grocery store. The bar was cluttered with used plates despite less than a quarter being occupied (this should have been the hint to go elsewhere). It's not that the food and drinks were bad, but in this city you need to bring your "A" game if you want a good rating.

E0hnzH2Kx50pYjIOhMxfuA.review_text: 7x7 100 Best Things To Eat in SF Before You Die 2014  #60 Frozen Custard with Egg Yolk Caramel   A very unique twist on caramel, frothy while thick in consistency. It was a harmonious pairing with the vanilla custard!   As for the custard, the texture was smooth and creamy. The vanilla flavor was definitely present but not overwhelming  We also tried the chocolate version which was good but didn't mesh as well with the caramel. They also had donuts that night in two different flavors so we ordered one of each. Can't recall the flavors but remember thinking that the donut was solid but nothing outstanding  Overall Thoughts  Vanilla Frozen Custard + Caramel = Brilliant

1wI3WRmx5IMOmxVx8k1Wrg.review_text: Fog City - formerly Fog City Diner - has been my go to place for lunch and dinner for many years. It's the type of place that you can just walk into without (for the most part) a reservation and have a great dining experience.   While I like the old Fog City a lot better, I'm glad they didn't scrap this place entirely as it's in such a great location and has always been consistent with the food quality. The old menu was a lot more extensive but I can appreciate with what they are trying to do with this revamped version. My only complaint is that while the old Fog City diner was unique and a hangout for SF elites, the new Fog city is very trendy and hipsterish and I can name at least 10 restaurants in the city just like it.   That being said, the bar is absolutely beautiful. The drinks are superb and the food, while simple, is certainty not pedestrian. Last time I had a beet salad and fried artichokes. I've also tried a very delicious kale salad, hamachi, the made to order doughnuts and a pudding dessert. They also have great ice cream. The menu changes pretty regularly, which I love. The bread and butter is also a very welcoming side of warm goodness. The service is spot on and the space is stunning with obvious attention to detail. Just go have a drink there and you'll see what I mean. All in all, a well rounded restaurant, albeit a bit too trendy, but worth trying at least once.

AGraTma9eEgsiJFDIy6tbg.review_text: It was a Monday night and we were in the area so we stopped by for a light dinner of kale salad (fresh, solid) and hamburger (not the best I've had but not bad).  The prices are a little high as compared to the quality of other SF restaurants.  The location is good and easy to get to by the Muni F line.  Service was friendly and attentive enough.

c8FOqDRhtL7q_YsQio6bog.review_text: So how do you know when you've had a great lunch? Answer: when you're still nibbling on the leftovers at dinner.  Case in point: my recent lunch at Fog City in SF. If you seeking a cool, unpretentious spot to power-lunch, look no further than this restaurant (which is conveniently located along the intersection of the Embarcadero and Levi Plaza). Added bonus: there's plenty of street parking + nearby parking lots!  My friends and I went to town with the lunch menu. The three of us split their famous deviled eggs (topped with crusted quinoa and bacon), as well as their new cherry tomato salad (which comes with lettuce, bacon, crumbled blue cheese/dressing). Once we finished devouring our small plates, we graduated to our main course. One of my friends got the burger (which is like a gourmet version of an In n Out burger) coupled with some crispy fries. My other friend went the more healthy route and ordered the kale salad with nuts, Spring veggies, watermelon radish, Persian cucumbers, and citrus vinaigrette. I, on the other hand, opted for the Saigon Dip (a Vietnamese inspired sandwich made with shaved roasted pork, spicy pickled vegetables, chili aioli, and cilantro). And to top it all off, the sandwich came with a large Pho dipping broth. It was as if a Vietnamese Banh mi and a French Dip came together and had a delicious love child. So good! I'm still flossing the roasted pork from my teeth.  For dessert, we split the house-made Frozen Custard. Admittedly, I don't have the biggest sweet tooth in the world. But this heavenly dish could easily convert me in to a custard believer.  This is my second visit to Fog City, and I'm just as satisfied with my meal as I was the first time. I love going to a restaurant that serves up classic favorites, but also continues to surprise you with new hits.   Keep up the great work, Fog City. I continue to be one of your biggest fans!

k0KEG3vrLkbK26PSiGb33A.review_text: I Remember the old Fog City Diner. You could go there for a basic, delicious American "Traditional" meal. Looked forward to the new Fog City (not Diner). This is true, not a diner and nothing about it is American "Traditional", whatever that is. Interesting main ingredients, but what they do to them is a little stretch, over the top, and doesn't seem to work.

KIYedTBi8L71-0vo_NNmBA.review_text: I've been here several times since the remodel, and each time it has been fine.  After tonight, though, I won't be going back.   Food: No complaints.  Service: Abysmal. Our waitress was an air-headed imbecile; she took our order, and then we didn't see her again until she decided that she needed to explain how to use the lemon garnish 45 minutes later. My wife had to ask the busboy for an iced tea refill after her glass remained empty for fifteen minutes. On that note, we tipped the busboys directly instead of the waitress, because they did her job for her; they delivered our food, brought us our refills, and cleared our table.  The icing on top: my friend explained the lacking quality of service to the manager as we were leaving, and he had the nerve to follow us out of the restaurant to accost us because of it. He insisted that he had personally delivered our food (he did not, it was the busboy), and he was adamant that he had come by three times to see how we were doing (he came by once.)  All we wanted to do was make him aware of a genuinely awful waitress; we would have still been back so long as we weren't seated in her section.  Instead, we will never be returning.   I have no tolerance for ignorant, rude, childish managers or incompetent waitstaff.  Props to the busboys though.

rOG1gDTZfsA6DL1OcAUfQA.review_text: The fries were cooked to have just the right amount of crisp to them but the taste of the cooking oil was just a touch to strong and noticeable.   The butter salad had fresh, flavorful greens and the smokey avocado dressing was a nice compliment. However, the salad just lacked that extra kick or special something.  For the entree I had the burger. I would not order it again. It was a little too wet with all the sauce and extras and the combination of a strangely sweet sauce and the bite from the pickles really didn't work well here. Keep it simple, put more focus on making the meat and bun taste is good as they can.  The ambiance was pretty good, the place was constructed with nice materials, like the rusted metal exterior, to make for a fresh look.   The server was friendly enough and did a good job checking in but could have been around a little more frequently, the kitchen was especially slow tonight and took about 2-3x as long to deliver our entrees as expected (for a couple other guests as well) but we didn't really hear anything about it from the waiter until after we had already been waiting for a good while.   Overall this restaurant has potential, it just needs to sharpen up the staff and refine their dishes a bit more.

38a_iS_B393A3f0ia6KYSQ.review_text: Awesome Christmas Eve dinner...Perry, our amazing waiter, took control of the meal. Delivered food, wine and prose with bravado. Frankly, best way to start a holiday!

LUnGfMkiEX5Wu8EF-ldBoQ.review_text: Great service, the broccoli and corn small plates were delicious! Everything is family style so it's great for sharing.
